editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A SHORT INTRODVCTION OF GRAMMAR Generally to be vſed: Compiled and ſet forth for the bringing vp of all thoſe that intend to attaine to the knowledge of the Latine TONGVE.
IMPRINTED BY CANTRELL LEGGE, Printer to the Vniuerſitie of CAMBRIDGE. 1621.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
TO exhort euery man to the learning of Grammar, that intendeth to attaine to the vnderſtanding of the tongues (wherin is contained a great treaſure of wiſedome and knowledge) it would ſeeme much vaine, and little needfull: for ſo much as it is knowne, that nothing can ſurely be ended, whoſe beginning is either feeble or faultie: and no building be perfect, when as the foundation & ground worke is ready to fall, and vnable to vphold the burden of the frame. Wherfore it were better for • he thing it ſelfe, and more profitable to the lear
• er, to vnderſtand how he may beſt come to that, which hee ought moſt neceſſarily to haue, and to • earne the gaineſt way of obtaining that, which muſt be his beſt and certaineſt guide, both of rea
• ing and ſpeaking, then to fall in doubt of the • oodnes and neceſſitie thereof. Which I doubt, • hether he ſhall more lament that he lacketh, or ſteeme that he hath it: and whether he ſhall oft
• er ſtumble in trifles, & be deceiued in light mat
• rs, when he hath it not, or iudge truly and faith
•• lly of diuers waightie things, when he hath it. The which hath ſeemed to many very hard to • mpaſſe aforetime, becauſe that they, who profeſ
• d this Art of teaching Grammar, did teach diers Grammars, and not one, and if by chance • ey taught one Grammar, yet they did it diuerſly,
and ſo could not do it all beſt, becauſe there is but one beſtneſſe, not onely in euery thing, but alſo in the manner of euery thing.

As for the diuerſity of Grammars, it is well and profitably taken away by the Kings Maieſties wiſedome, who foreſeeing the inconuenience, and fauourably prouiding the remedie, cauſed one kind of Grammar by ſundry learned men to be diligently drawne, and ſo to be ſet out, onely euery where to be taught for the vſe of learners, and for the hurt in changing of Schoolemaſters.

The varietie of teaching is diuers yet, and alwayes will be, for that euery Schoolemaſter liketh that he knoweth, and ſeeth not the vſe of that he knoweth not, and therefore iudgeth that the moſt ſufficient way, which he ſeeth to be the readieſt meane, and perfecteſt kind, to bring a learner to haue a through knowledge therein.

Wherefore it is not amiſſe, if one ſeeing by triall an eaſier and readier way, then the common ſort of teachers do, would ſay what he hath prooued, and for the commodity allowed, that other not knowing the ſame, might by experience proue the like; and then by proofe reaſonable iudge the like • not hereby excluding the better way when it is found, but in the meane ſeaſon forbidding the worſe.

The firſt and • heifeſt point is, that the diligent Maſter make not the Scholler haſt too much, but that in continuance and diligence of teaching make him to rehearſe ſo, that while he hath perfectly that that is behind, he ſuffer him not to goe forward. For this poſting haſt, ouerthroweth and hurteth a great ſort of wits, and caſteth them into an amazedneſſe, when they know not how they ſhall either go forward or backeward, but ſticke
faſt as one plunged, that cannot tell what to doe, or which way to turne him: and then the Maſter thinketh the Scholler to be a dullard, and the Scholler thinketh the thing to be vneaſie, and too hard for his wit: and the one hath an euill opinion in the other, when oftentimes it is in neither, but in the kind of teaching. Wherefore, the beſt and cheifeſt point throughly to bee kept is, that the Scholler haue in minde ſo perfectly that that hee hath learned, and vnderſtand it ſo, that not onely it be not a ſtoppe for him, but alſo a light and help vnto the reſidue that followeth. This ſhall be the Maſters eaſe, and the childes incouraging, when the one ſhall ſee his labour take good effect, and thereby in teaching the leſſe tormented: and the other ſhall thinke the thing the eaſier, and ſo with more gladneſſe readie to goe about the ſame.

In going forward, let him haue of euery declination of Nounes, and coniugation of Verbes, ſo many ſeuerall examples as they paſſe them, that it may ſeeme to the Schoolemaſter no word in the Latine tongue to be ſo hard for that part, that the Scholler ſhall not be able praiſeably to enter into the fourming thereof. And ſurely the multitude of examples, if the eaſieſt and commoneſt bee taken firſt, and ſo come to the ſtranger and harder, muſt
• eedes bring this profit withall, that the Scholler ſhall beſt vnderſtand, and ſooneſt conceiue the reaſon of the rules, and beſt be acquainted with the faſhion of the tongue. Wherein it is profitable, not onely that he can orderly decline his Noune, and his Verbe, but euery way, forward, backward, by • aſes, by perſons: that neither caſe of Noune, nor perſon of Verbe can be required, that hee cannot without ſtop or ſtudy tell. And vnto this time I count not the Scholler perfect, nor ready to goe any
further, till he hath this alreadie learned.

This when he can perfectly doe, and hath learned euery part, not by rote but by reaſon, and is cunninger in the vnderſtanding of the thing, then in rehearſing of the words, (which is not paſt a quarter of a yeares diligence, or very little more to a painfull and diligent man, if the Scholler haue a meane wit) then let him paſſe to the Concords to know the agreement of parts among themſelues, with like way and diligence, as is afore deſcribed.

Wherein plaine and ſundry examples, and continuall rehearſall of things learned, and ſpecially the daily declining of a Verbe, and turning him into all faſhions, ſhall make the great and heaute labour ſo eaſie, and ſo pleaſant for the framing of ſentences, that it wil be rather a delight vnto them that they be able to do well, then paine in ſearching of an vnuſed and vnacquainted thing.

When theſe Concordes bee well knowne vnto them, an eaſie and a pleaſant paine, if the foregrounds be well and throughly beaten in, let them not continue in learning of their rules orderly, as they lie in the Syntaxe, but rather learne ſome prettie booke, wherein is contained not only the eloquence of the tongue, but alſo a good plaine leſſon of honeſtie and godlines, and thereof take ſome little ſentence as it lieth, and learne to make the ſame firſt out of Engliſh into Latine, not ſeeing the booke, or conſtruing it thereupon. And if there fal any neceſſary rule of the Syntaxe to be known, then to learne it, as the occaſion of the ſentence giueth cauſe that day. Which ſentence once made well, and as nigh as may be with the words of the booke, then to take the booke, and conſtrue it, and ſo ſhall he be leſſe troubled with the parſing of it, and eaſilieſt carry his leſſon in minde.

And although it was ſaid before, that the ſcholler ſhould learne but a little at once, it is not meant that when the Maſter hath heard him a while, he ſhould let him alone, (for that were more negligence for both parts) but I would all their time they be at ſchoole, they ſhould neuer be idle, but alwayes occupied in a continuall rehearſing and looking backe againe to thoſe things they haue learned, and be more bound to keep well their old, then to take forth any new.

Thus if the Maſter occupy them, he ſhall ſee a little leſſon take a great deale of time: and diligently enquiring and examining of the parts and the rules, not to bee done ſo quickly and ſpeedily as it might be thought to be: within a while, by this vſe the Scholler ſhal be brought to a good kind of readineſſe of making, to the which if there be adioyned ſome vſe of ſpeaking, (which muſt neceſſarily be had) he ſhall be brought paſt the weariſome bitternes of his learning.

A great helpe to further this readineſſe of making and ſpeaking ſhall be, if the Maſter giue him an Engliſh booke, and cauſe him ordinarily to turne euery day ſome part into Latine. This exerciſe cannot be done without his rules, and therfore doth eſtabliſh them and ground them ſurely in his mind for readines, and maketh him more able to ſpeake ſuddenly, whenſoeuer any preſent occaſion is offered for the ſame. And it doth help his learning more a great deale to turne out of Engliſh into Latine, then contrary.

Furthermore, we ſee many can vnderſtand Latine, that cannot ſpeake it, and when they reade the Latine word in the booke, can tell you the Engliſh thereof at any time: but when they haue layd away their bookes, they cannot contrariwiſe tell
you for the Engliſh the Latine againe, whenſoeuer you will aske them. And therefore this exerciſe helpeth this ſore well, and maketh thoſe words which hee vnderſtandeth to be readieſt by vſe vnto him, and ſo perfecteth him in the tongue handſomely.

Theſe precepts well kept, will bring a man cleane paſt the vſe of this Grammar booke, and make him as ready as his book, and ſo meet to further things: whereof it were out of ſeaſon to giue precepts here. And therefore this may be for this purpoſe enough, which to good Schoolemaſters and ſkilfull are not ſo needfull: to other meaner and leſſe practiſed it may be, not onely worth the labour of reading, but alſo of the vſing.
The LATINE Letters are thus WRITTEN.

div.p: Letters are diuided into VOWELS and CONSONANTS.
A Vowell is a Letter, which maketh a full and perfect ſound of himſelfe: and there are fiue in number, namely, A. E. I. O. V. whereunto is added the Greeke Vowell Y.
A Conſonant is a Letter, which muſt needes be ſounded with a Vowell: as B. with E. And all the Letters, except the Vowels, are Conſonants.
A Syllable is the Pronouncing of one Letter, or moe with one breath: as, A • ue.

A Diphthong is the ſound of two Vowels in one ſyllable, and of them there be foure in number, name
• y, ae, oe, au, eu: whereunto is added ei: as A •• eas, Coens, Audio, Euge, Hei.

In ſtead of
•• , and oe, we commonly do pronounce E.
The GREEKE Letters are thus WRITTEN.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

div.head: PRECATIO.
div.p: DOmine Pater coeli ac terrae effector, qui liberaliter tribuis ſapientiam omnibus eam cum fiducia abs te petentibus, exorna ingenij mei bonitatem, quam cum caeteris naturae viribus mihi infudiſti, lumine diuinae gratiae tuae, vt non modo quae ad cognoſcendum te, & Seruatorem noſtrum Dominum Ieſum valeant intelligam: ſed etiam ita mente & voluntate perſequar, & indies benignitate tua, tum doctrina tum pietate proficiam, vt, qui efficis omnia in omnibus, in me reſplendeſeere dona tua facias, ad gloriam ſempiternam immortalis Maieſtatis tuae, Amen.

p.hi: O Almightie Lord & mercifull Father, maker of Heauen and Earth, which of thy free liberalitie giueſt wiſedome aboundantly to all that with faith and full aſſurance aske it of thee: beautifie by the light of thy heauenly grace the towardnes of my wit, the which with all powers of nature thou haſt powred into me, that I may not onely vnderſtand thoſe things which may effectually bring me to the knowledge of thee, and the Lord Ieſu our Sauiour, but alſo with my whole heart and will, conſtantly follow the ſame, and receiue daily increaſe through thy bountiful goodneſſe towards me, as well in good life as doctrine, ſo that thou which workeſt all things in all creatures, maiſt make thy gratious benefits ſhine in me, to the endleſſe glorie and honour of thine immortall Maieſtie. So be it.

div.head: An Introduction of the Eight parts of LATINE SPEECH.

p.hi: IN Speech be theſe eight parts following:

list.item: Noune, declined. Aduerbe, vndeclined.
Pronoune, declined. Coniunction vndeclined.
Verbe, declined. Prepoſition, vndeclined.
Participle, declined. Interiection vndeclined.

div.head: OF A NOVNE.
div.p: A Noune, A Noune. is the name of a thing that may beſeen, felt, heard, or vnderſtood; as the name of my hand in Latine, is Manus: the name of an houſe, is Domus: the namé of goodnes, is Bonitas.

p.hi: Of Nounes, ſome be Subſtantiues, Nounes be o • two ſorts. and ſome be Adiectiues.

div.p: A noune Subſtantiue is that ſtandeth by himſelfe, A Noune Subſtantiue. and requireth not another word to be ioyned with him to ſhewe his ſignification: as Homo, a man. And it is declined with one Article: as Hic magiſter, a maſter. Or elſe with two at the moſt: as Hic & Haec Parens, a father or mother.

A noune Adiectiue is that cannot ſtand by himſelfe in reaſon or ſignification, A Noune Adiectiue. but requireth to be ioyned with an other word: as Bonus, Good. Pulcher, Faire. And it is declined either with three Terminations: as Bonus, bona, bonum: or elſe with three Articles: as Hic, haec, & hoc Foelix, Happie. Hic & haec Leuis, & hoc Leue, Light.
A Noune Subſtantiue, Two kinds of Nounes Subſtantiues. either is proper to the thing that it betokeneth, as Edvardus is my proper name: or elſe is common to moe, as Homo is a common name to all men.

div.head: Numbers of Nounes.
div.p:
IN Nounes be two numbers, the Singular and the Plurall. The Singular number ſpeaketh
but of one: as Lapis, a ſtone. The Plurall number ſpeaketh of moe then one: as Lapides, ſtones.

div.head: Caſes of Nounes.

p.hi: NOunes be declined with ſixe caſes, ſingularly and plurally: The Nominatiue, the Genitiue, the Datiue, the Accuſatiue, the Vocatiue, and the Ablatiue.

div.p: The Nominatiue caſe commeth before the verb, Nominatiue caſe. and anſwereth to this queſtion, Who, or what: as Magiſter docet, The Maſter teacheth.
The Genitiue caſe is known by this token Of, Genitiue. and anſwereth to this queſtion, Whoſe, or whereof: as Doctrina magiſtri, The learning of the Master.
The Datiue caſe is known by this token To, Datiue. & anſwereth to this queſtion, To whom, or to what: as Do librum magiſtro, I giue a booke to the Maſter.
The Accuſatiue caſe followeth the Verbe, Accuſatiue. and anſwereth to this queſtion, Whome, or what: as Amo magiſtrum, I loue the Maſter.
The Vocatiue caſe is known by calling or ſpeaking to: Vocatiue. as O Magiſter, O Maſter.
The Ablatiue caſe is cōmonly ioyned with Prepoſitions ſeruing to the Ablatiue caſe: Ablatiue. as De Magiſtro, Of the Maſter: Coram Magiſtro, Before the Maſter.

p.hi: Alſo In, with, through, for, from, by, & then, after ye comparatiue degree, be ſignes of ye ablatiue caſe.
ARticles are borrowed of the Pronoune, and be thus declined,

div.head: Genders of Nounes.

p.hi: GEnders of Nounes be ſeuen: the Maſculine, the Feminine, the Neuter, ye Common of two, ye Common of three, the Doubtful, & the Epicene.

div.p: The Maſculine Gender is declined with this Article Hic: as Hic vir, a man.
The Feminine Gender is declined with this article Haec: as Hec mulier, a woman.
The Neuter Gender is declined with this article Hoc: as Hoc ſaxum, a flone.
The Common of two is declined with Hic and Haec: as Hic & Haec Parens, a father or mother.
The Common of three is declined with Hic, haec and hoc: as Hic, haec & hoc foelix, happie.
The Doubtfull Gender is declined with Hic or Haec: as Hic vel haec dies, a day.
The Epicene Gender is declined with one article, and vnder that one article both kinds be ſignified: as Hic paſſer, a ſparrow. Haec aquila, an Eagle, both he and ſhee.

div.head: The Declenſions of Nounes.
There be fiue Declenſions of Nounes.
div.p:
THe firſt is when the Genitiue & the datiue caſe ſingular do end in ae diphthong, the accuſatiue in am, the Vocatiue like the Nominatiue, the Ablatiue in a. The Nominatiue plurall in ae diphthong, the Genitiue in arum, the Datiue in is, the Accuſatiue in as, the Vocatiue like the Nominatiue, the Ablatiue in is: as in example,
Singulariter,
Nominat. haec muſa
Genit. huius muſae
Datiuo huic muſae
Accuſ. hanc muſam
Vocatiuo ô muſa
Ablat. ab hac muſa
Pluraliter,
Nominatiue hae muſae Haec Menſa. Hic Poëta. Hic & haec Verna.
Genit. harum muſarum
Dat. his muſis
Accuſat. has muſas
Vocatiuo ô muſae
Ablatiuo ab hic muſis.
Note that Filia and Nata, Note. doe make the Datiue and the Ablatiue plurall in is or in abus. Alſo Dea, mula, equa, liberta, make the Datiue and the Ablatiue caſe plurall in abus onely.

THe ſecond is,
when the Genitiue caſe ſingular endeth in i, the Datiue in o, the Accuſatiue in um, the Vocatiue for the moſt part like the Nominatiue, the Ablatiue in o. The Nominatiue plurall in i, the Genitiue in orum, the Datiue in is, the Accuſatiue in os, the Vocatiue like the Nominatiue, the Ablatiue in is: as in example,
Singulariter,
Nomin. hic magiſter Hic Vir. Hic Liber. Haec Colus. Hic Logos.
Gen. huius magiſtri
Datiuo huic magiſtro
Acc. hunc magiſtrum
Vocatiuo ô magiſter
Ablat. ab hoc magiſtro
Pluraliter,
Nominatiuo hi magiſtri
Gen. horum magiſtrorum
Datiuo his magiſtris.
Accuſatiuo hos magiſtros
Ʋocatiuo ô magiſtri
Ablat. ab his magiſtris.
Here is to be noted, that when the Nominatiue endeth in us, the Vocatiue ſhall end in e: as Nominatiuo hic Dominus, Vocatiuo ô Domine. Except Deus that maketh ô Deus: and Filius, that maketh ô Fili.
When the Nominatiue endeth in ius, if it be a proper name of a man, the Vocatiue ſhall end in i: as, Nominatiuo hic Georgius, Vocatiuo ô Georgi.
Alſo theſe Nounes following, make their vocatiue in c, or in us: as Agnus, lucus, vulgus, populus, chorus, fluvius.

p.hi: Note alſo, Note. that all Nounes of the neuter gender, of what declenſion foeuer they be, haue the Nominatiue, the Accuſatiue, and the Vocatiue like in both numbers, and in the plurall number they end all in a: as in example,

item.note: Hoc damnum Hoc Malum. Hoc Verbum.

div.p:
Except Ambo and Duo, which make the Neuter gender in o, and be thus declined,
Pluraliter,
Nominatiuo Ambo, ambae, ambo
Genitiuo Amborum, ambarum, amborum
Datiuo Ambobus, ambabus, ambobus
Accuſatiuo Ambos, ambas, ambo
Vocatiuo Ambo, ambae, ambo
Ablat. Ambobus, ambabus, ambobus. Like wiſe Duo.

THe third is, when the Genitiue caſe ſingular endeth in is, the Datiue in i, ye Accuſatiue moſt commonly in em, & ſometime in im, and ſometime in both: the Vocatiue like the Nominatiue, ye Ablatiue in e, ſometime in i, & ſometime both in e & i: The Nominatiue caſe plurall in es, the Genitiue ſometime in um, & ſometime in ium, the Datiue in • us, the Accuſatiue in es, the Vocatiue like the Nominatiue, the Ablatiue in bus: as in example,
Singulariter,
Nominatiuo hic lapis
Genit. huius lapidis
Datiuo huic lapidi
Accuſ. hunc lapidem
Vocatiuo ô lapis
Ablat. ab hoc lapide
Pluraliter,
Nominatiuo hi lapides Hic pater. Hic pani • . Hoc opus. Hoc caput. Haec nubes.
Genit. horum lapidum
Datiuo his lapidibus
Accuſatiuo hos lapides
Vocatiuo ô lapides
Ablat. ab his lapidibus.
Singulariter,
Nom. hic & hae parens
Genit. huius parentis
Datiuo huic parenti
A. hunc & hāc parentē
Vocatiuo ô parens
A. ab hoc & hac parente
Pluraliter,
Nom. hi & hae parentes Hic vel haec bubo. Haec virtus. Hoc animal. Hoc cubile. Hoc calcar.
G. horū & harū parentum
Da. his parentibus
A. hos & has parentes
Vocatiuo ô parentes
Ab. ab his parentibus.

THe fourth is, when the Genitiue caſe ſingular endeth in us, ye datiue in üi, ye accuſatiue in um, the vocatiue like ye Nominatiue, the ablatiue in u. The nominatiue plurall in us, ye genitiue in ünm, ye datiue in ibus, ye accuſatiue in us, the vocatiue like the nominatiue, ye ablatiue in ibus: as in example,
Singulariter,
Nominatiuo haec manus
Genitiuo huius manus Hic Gradus. Haec porticus. Hoc Cornu.
Datiuo huic manui
Accuſat. hanc manum
Vocatiuo ô manus
Ablatiuo ab hac manu
Pluraliter,
Nominatiuo hae manus
Gen. harum manuum
Datiuo his manibus
Accuſatiuo has manus
Vocatiuo ô manus
Ablat. ab his manibus

THe fift is, when the Genitiue & the datiue caſe ſingular do end in ei, the Accuſatiue in em, the vocatiue like the nominatiue, ye ablatiue in e. The Nominatiue plurall in es, ye Genitiue in erum, the datiue in ebus, the accuſatiue in es, ye vocatiue like the nominatiue, ye ablatiue in obus: as in example,
Singulariter,
Nominatiuo hic meridies Haec Res. Haec Facies. Haec Acies.
Genitiuo huius meridei
Datiuo huic meridei
Accuſat. hunc meridiem
Ʋocatiuo ô meridies
Ablatiuo ab hoc meridie
Pluraliter,
Nominat. hi meridies
G. horum meridierum
Dat. his meridiebus
Accuſat. hos meridies
Ʋocatiuo ô meridies
Ab. ab his meridiebus
Note that all nounes of the fifth declenſion bee of the feminine gender, except meridies, Note. and dies.

div.head: The Declining of Adiectiues.

p.hi: A Noune Adiectiue of three terminations is thus declined,

item.hi: No. bonus, Niger, a, um. Tardus, a, um. Satur, a, um. bona, bonū

div.p:
There are beſide theſe, An exception. certaine Nounes adiectiues of another maner of declining, which make the genitiue caſe ſingular in ïus, and the datiue in i, which be theſe that follow, with their cōpounds.
Singulariter,
No. vnus, vna, vnum
Genitiuo vnius
Datiuo vni
Ac. vnum, vnā, vnū
Vo. vne, vna, vnum
Ablat. vno, vna, vno
Pluraliter,
Nomin. vni, vnae, vna
G. vnorum, vnarū, vnorum
Dat. vnis
Accuſ. vnos. vnas. vna
Vocat. vni, vnae, vna
Ablatiuo vnis.
Note that vnus, a, um, Note. hath not the plural number, but when it is ioyned with a word that lacketh ye ſingular number: as, vnae literae, vna moenia.

In like manner be declined totus, ſolus, Nounes Adiectiues lacking the vocatiue caſe. and alſo vllus, alius
〈…〉
vter, and neuter, ſauing that theſe fiue laſt re ••• ſed, lacke the Vocatiue caſe.

p.hi: A noune adiectiue of in, articles, is thus declined:

item.hi: Ab. ab hoc, hac, & hoc foelice vel foelici
Nomin. hi & hae foelices & haec foelicia
Ac. hos & has foelices & haec foelicia
No. hic & haec triſtis & hoc triſte
Accuſ. hunc & hanc triſtem, & hoc triſte
Ablat. ab hoc, hac & hoc triſti

item.note: Leuis, & leue, Celer, celeris & celere. Melior & melius.

item.hi: Acc. hos & has triſtes & haec triſtia

div.head: Compariſons of Nounes.
div.p: A Diectiues whoſe ſignifications may increaſe or be diminiſhed, Three degree, of cō pariſon. The Poſitiue. may forme Compariſon.

p.hi: There be three degrees of compariſon: The Poſitiue, the Comparatiue, and the Superlatiue.

div.p: The Poſitiue betokeneth the thing abſolutely without exceſſe: as, Durus, Hard.

The Comparatiue ſomwhat exceedeth his poſitiue in ſignification: The Comparatiue. as, Durior, Harder. And it is formed of the firſt caſe of his poſitiue that endeth in i, by putting thereto, or & us: as of Duri, hic & haec durior, & hoc durius: of Triſti. hic & hec triſtior, & hoc triſtius: of Dulci, hic & haec dulcior, & hoc dulcius.

The Superlatiue exceedeth hi •
•• ſitiue in the higheſt degree: The Superlatiue. as, Duriſſimus,
〈…〉 And it is formed of the firſt caſe of his Poſ ••••• that endeth in i, by putting thereto ſand ſimus: as of Duri, duriſſimus: of Triſti, triſtiſſimus: of Dulci, dulciſſimus

From theſe general rules are excepted theſe tha • follow: Exception. Bonus, melior, optimus: Malus, peior, peſſimu • Magn • s, maior, maximus. Parvus, minor, minimu • Multus plurimus, multa plurima, multum plus plu • mum.

And if the Poſitiue end in er, Ater. Teter. Accv. the Superlati •• is formed of the Nominatiue caſe, by putting
• rimus: as Pulcher, pulcherrimus.

Alſo theſe Nounes ending in lis, make the Sparlatiue by changing lis into limus: as, Humil humillimus ſimilis, ſimillimus: facilis, facillimus: g •
cilis, graci • limus: agilis, agillimus: docilis, docillim •
All other Nounes ending in lis, doe followe 〈◊〉 generall ruſe aforegoing: Ignens. Imp •• s. Ardum. Strenuus. as, Vtilis, vtiliſſimus.
Alſo if a vowell come before us, it is compa • by Magis & Maximè: as Pius, magis pius, maximè us. Aſsiduus, magis aſsiduus, maximè aſſiduus.

div.head: Of the PRONOVNE.

p.hi: APronoune, is a part of ſpeech much like to a Noune, which is vſed in ſhewing or rehearſing.

div.p:
There be fifteene Pronounes, Ego, tu, ſui, ille, There be ſ ••
teene Pronounes. ipſe, iſte, hic, is, meus, tuus, ſuus, noſter, veſter, noſtras, veſtras, whereof foure haue the vocatiue caſe: as, Tu, meus, noſter, and noſtras, and all the other lacke the Vocatiue caſe.
To theſe may be added their compounds, Egomer, tute, idem, and alſo Qui, quae, quod.

Theſe eight Pronounes, Ego, tu, ſui, ille, ipſe, Pronounes • Primitiues. iſte, hic, & is, be Primitiues, ſo called, for becauſe they be not deriued of others. And they be alſo called Demonſtratiues, Demonſtratiues. becauſe they ſhewe a thing not ſpoken of before.
And theſe ſixe, Hic, ille, iſte, is, idem, and qui, Relatiues. be Relatiues, becauſe they rehearſe a thing that was ſpoken of before.
Theſe ſeauen Meus, tuus, ſuus, noſter, veſter, Deriuatiues. noſtras, veſtras, be Deriuatiues, for they bee deriued of their Primitiues, Mei, tui, ſui, noſtri, and veſtri.

p.hi: There belong to a Pronoune theſe tïue things: Fiue things belonging to a Pronoune. Number, Caſe, and Gender, as are in a Noune: Declenſion and Perſon, as here followeth.

div.head: The Declenſions of PRONOVNES.
There be foure Declenſions of Pronounes.

p.hi: Theſe three, Ego, tu, ſui,
be of the firſt declenſſon, and he thus declined.

div.p: Theſe ſixe, The ſecond declenſion. Ille, ipſe, iſte, hic, is, and qui, bee of the ſecond declenſion, and be thus declined.
Ille, is declined like Iſte, and alſo Ipſe, ſauing that the neuter gender in the Nominatiue caſe and in the Accuſatiue caſe ſingular maketh Ipſum.
Nominatiuo hic, haec, hoc: Genitiuo huius: Datiu • huic, as afore in the Noune.

item.hi: Abl. quo, qua, quo, vel qui

div.p:
Likewiſe Quis and Quid be declined, The compound of Quis. wheth •• they be Interrogatiues, or Indefinits, Alſo Qu •
quis is thus declined:

p.hi: Nom.

item.hi: Quiſquis. Accuſ. Quicquid. Abl. Quoquo, Quaqua, Quoquo.
Quicquid. Accuſ. Quicquid. Abl. Quoquo, Quaqua, Quoquo.

div.p: Where note that Quid is alwaies a Subſtantiue of the Neuter gender. Note.

Theſe fiue, Meus, tuus, ſuus, noſter, & veſter, The thirddeclenſion. are of the third declenſion, and be declined like nounes Adiectiues of three terminations, in this wiſe:
Singulariter,
Nom. meus, mea, meum
Gen. mei, meae, mei
Dat. meo, meae, meo
Ac. meum, meā, meum
Ʋocat. mi, mea, meum
Ablat. meo, mea, meo
Pluraliter,
Nom. mei, meae, mea
Gen. meorum, mearum
Dat. meis
Acc. meos, meas, mea meorum
Ʋoc. mei, meae, mea
Ablatiuomeis
So is Noſter declined, and Tuus, ſuus, veſter, ſauing that theſe three laſt do lack the vocatiue caſe

Noſtras, Veſtras, and this noune Cuias, The fourth declenſion. be of the fourth declenſion, and be thus declined:
Singulariter,
Nom hic & haec noſtras, & hoc noſtrate
Gen. huius noſtratis
Datiuo huic noſtrati
A. hūc & hanc noſtratem & hoc noſtrate
Vocat. ô noſtras, & ô noſtrate
Abl. hoc, hac, & hoc noſtrate, velnoſtrati
Pluraliter,
Nom. hi & he noſtrates & haec noſtratia
Gen. horum, harum, & horum noſtratium.
Dat. his noſtratibus
Acc. hos & has noſtrates, & haec noſtratia
Ʋocat. ô noſtrates, & ô noſtratia
Abl. ab his noſtratibus.
Here is to be noted, that Noſtras, Veſtras, Note. and his Noune Cuias, be called Gentiles, becauſe they properly betoken pertaining to countries or nations, to ſects or factions.

div.head: A Pronoune hath three perſons.
div.p:
The firſt perſon ſpeaketh of himſelfe: as, Ego, Perſons three.
〈◊〉 : Nos, wee.
The ſecond perſon is ſpoken to: as, Tu, Thou: Vos, Yee. And of this perſon is alſo euery vocatiue caſe.
The third perſon is ſpoken of: as, Ille, He: Illi, They. And therefore all Nounes, Pronounes, and Participles be of the third perſon.

div.head: Of a VERBE.
div.p: A Verbe is a part of ſpeech, A verbe. declined with moode and tenſe, and betokeneth doing: as, Amo, I loue: or ſuffering, as, Amor, I amaoued: or beeing, as, Sum, I am.
Of verbes, ſuch as haue perſons, be called Perſonals: as, Ego amo, Tu amas. And ſuch as haue no perſons, be called Imperſonals: as, Taedet, It irketh. Oportet, It behooueth.

p.hi: Of verbs Perſonals there be fiue kinds: Verbes Perſonals. Actiue, Paſſiue, Neuter, Deponent, and Commune.

div.p: A verbe Actiue endeth in o, Actiue. and betokeneth to doe: as, Amo, I loue: and by putting to r, it may be a Paſſiue: as, Amor.
A verbe Paſſiue endeth in or, Paſſiue. and betokeneth to ſuffer: as, Amor, I am loued: and by putting away r, it may be an Actiue: as, Amo.

A verbe Neuter endeth in o, Neuter. or m, and cannot take r, to make him a Paſſiue: as, Curro, I runne •
Sum, I am. And it is engliſhed ſometime actiuely: as, Curro, I runne: And ſometime paſſiuely as, Aegroto, I am ſicke.
A verb deponent endeth in r, Deponent. like a Paſſiue, an • yee in ſignification is but either Actiue, as Loqu • verbum, I ſpeake a word • or neuter, as, Glorior, I boaſt.
A verbe Commune endeth in r, Commune. and in ſignification is both Actiue and Paſſiue: as, Oſculor to I kiſſe thee: Oſeulor à re. I am kiſſed of thee.

div.head: MOODES.

p.hi: THere be ſixe Moodes: the Indicatiue, Moodes ſixe. the Imperatiue, the Optatiue, the Potentiall, the Subiunctiue, and the Infinitiue.

div.p: The Indicatiue moode ſheweth a reaſon true or falſe: as, Ego amo, I loue. Indicatiue. Or els asketh a queſtion: as, Amas tu? Doeſt thou loue?
The Imperatiue biddeth or commandeth: as, Imperatiue Ama, Loue thou.
The Optatiue wiſheth or deſireth, Optatiue. with theſe ſigues, would God, I pray God, or God grant: as, Vtinam amem, I pray God I loue: and hath euermore an Aduerbe of wiſhing ioyned with him.

p.hi: The Potentiall mood is known by theſe ſignes,
May, can, might, would, ſhould, or ought: as, Amem, I may or can loue: without an Aduerbe ioyned with him.

div.p:
The Subiunctiue moode hath euermore ſome Coniunction ioyned with hm: as, Cùm amarem, Subiunctiue.
when I loued. And it is called ye Subiunctiue mood, becauſe it dependeth of another verbe in the ſame • entence, either going afore, or comming after: as, Cùm amarem, eram miſer: when I loued, I was a wretch.

The Infinitiue ſignifieth to doe, to ſuffer, Infinitiue. or to • e, and hath neither number, nor perſon, nor Nominatiue caſe before him, and is known common
• y by this ſigne, To: as, Amare, To loue. Alſo when • wo verbes come together, without any Nomina
• ue caſe between them, then the latter ſhal be the • nfinitiue mood: as, Cupio diſcere, I deſire to learne.

div.head: GERVNDES.
div.p:
THere be moreouer belonging to the Infinitiue moode of Verbes, Gerundes three, Di, de, dum. certaine voices called Ge
• nds, ending in Di, do, and dum: which haue both • e Actiue and Paſſiue ſignification: as, Amandi,
Of louing, or of beeing loued. Amando, In louing, or in beeing loued. Amandum, To loue, or to be loued.

div.head: SVPINES.
div.p: THere be alſo pertaining vnto Verbs two Supines, Supines two, 〈◊〉 , u. the one ending in um, which is called the firſt ſupine, becauſe it hath the ſignification of the verbe actiue: as, Eo amatum, I goe to loue. And the other in u, which is called the latter Supine, becauſe it hath for the moſt part the ſignification paſſiue: as, Difficilis amatu, Hard to be loued.

div.head: TENSES.

p.hi: THere be fiue Tenſes or Times: Tenſes fiue. the Preſent tenſe, the Preterimperfect tenſe, the Preterperfect, the Preterpluperfect, & the Future tenſe.

div.p: The Preſent tenſe ſpeaketh of the time that now is: Preſent tenſe. as Amo, I loue.
The Preterimperfect tenſe ſpeaketh of the time not perfectly paſt: Preterimperfect. as, Amabam, I loued, or did loue.

p.hi: The Preterperfect tenſe ſpeaketh of ye time perfectly paſt, Preterperfect wt this ſigne Haue: as, Amaui, I haue loued.

div.p: The Preterpluperfect tenſe ſpeaketh of the time more then perfectly paſt, Preterpluperfect. with this ſigne Had: as, Amaueram, I had loued.
The Future tenſe ſpeaketh of the time to come, Future. with this ſigne Shal or wil: as, Amabo, I ſhal or wil lou •

div.head: PERSONS.
div.p:
THere be alſo in Verbes three perſons, Perſons three. in both numbers: as, Singulariter, Ego amo, I loue: T •
amas, Thou loueſt: Ille amat, He loueth. Pluralit. Nos amamus, We loue: Vos amatis, Ye loue: Illiamant, They lou •

div.head: CONIVGATIONS.

p.hi: VErbes haue foure Coniugations, Coniugations foure. which be • knowne after this manner:

div.p:
The firſt Coniugation hath â long before re,
and
〈◊〉 : as, Amâre, Amâris.

The ſecond Coniugation hath ê long before re,
and
〈◊〉 : as, Docê e, Docêris.

The third Coniugation hath ĕ ſhort before re,
and
〈◊〉 : as, Legĕre, legĕris.

The fourth Coniugation hath î long before re,
and
〈◊〉 : as, Audîre, Audîris.

div.head: Verbes in O, of the foure Coniugations bee declined after theſe examples.
div.p: AMo, amas, amaui, amare: Amandi, amando, amandum: Amatum, amatu: Amans, amaturus. To loue
Doceo, doces, docui, docere: Docendi, docendo, docendum: Doctum, doctu: Docens, docturus. To teach.
Lego, legis, legi, legere: Legendi, legendo, legendum: Lectum, lectu: Legens, lecturus. To reade.
Audio, audis, audiui, audire: Audiendi, audiendo, audiendum: Auditum, audiru: Audiens, auditurus. To heare.

list.head: I loued, or did loue. Preterimperfect tenſe ſingular,
list.item: Amabam, bas, bat. Plural. bamus, batis, bant.
Docebam, bas, bat. Plural. bamus, batis, bant.
Legebam, bas, bat. Plural. bamus, batis, bant.
Audiebam, bas, bat. Plural. bamus, batis, bant.

list.head: I haue loued. Preterperfect tenſe ſingular,
list.item: Amaui, iſti, it. Plural. imus, iſtis, êrunt vel êre.
Docui, iſti, it. Plural. imus, iſtis, êrunt vel êre.
Legi, iſti, it. Plural. imus, iſtis, êrunt vel êre.
Audiui, iſti, it. Plural. imus, iſtis, êrunt vel êre.

list.head: I had loued. Preterpluperfect tenſe ſingular,
list.item: Amaueram, ras, rat. Plural. ramus, ratis, rant.
Docueram, ras, rat. Plural. ramus, ratis, rant.
Legeram, ras, rat. Plural. ramus, ratis, rant.
Audiueram, ras, rat. Plural. ramus, ratis, rant.

list.head: I ſhall or will loue. Future tenſe ſingular,
list.item: Amabo, bis, bit. Pluraliter bimus, bitis, bunt.
Docebo, bis, bit. Pluraliter bimus, bitis, bunt.
Legam, es, •• . Pluraliter emus, etis, ent.
Audiam, es, •• . Pluraliter emus, etis, ent.

p.hi: Preſent tenſe ſingular,

cell.hi: Loue he, or let him loue.
Loue we, or let vs loue.
Loue they, or let them loue.

list.head: God grant I loue. Preſent tenſe ſingular, Vtinam,
list.item: Amem, ames, amet. Plural. amemus, ametis, mene.
Doceam, as, at. Plural. vtinam amus, atis, ant.
Legam, as, at. Plural. vtinam amus, atis, ant.
Audiam, as, at. Plural. vtinam amus, atis, ant.

list.head: Would God I loued, or did loue. Preterimperfect tenſe ſingular, Vtinā
list.item: Amarem, res, ret. Plu. vtinam remus, retis, rent.
Docerem, res, ret. Plu. vtinam remus, retis, rent.
Legerem, res, ret. Plu. vtinam remus, retis, rent.
Audirem, res, ret. Plu. vtinam remus, retis, rent.

list.head: I pray God I haue loued: Preterperfect tenſe ſingular, Vtinam,
list.item: Amauerim, ris, rit. Plural. vtin. rimus, ritis, rint.
Docuerim, ris, rit. Plural. vtin. rimus, ritis, rint.
Legerim, ris, rit. Plural. vtin. rimus, ritis, rint.
Audiuerim, ris, rit. Plural. vtin. rimus, ritis, rint.

list.head: Would God I had loued. Preterpluperfect tenſe ſingular, Vtin.
list.item: Amauiſſem, ſes, ſet. Plur. vtinam ſemus, ſetis, ſent.
Docuiſſem, ſes, ſet. Plur. vtinam ſemus, ſetis, ſent.
Legiſſem, ſes, ſet. Plur. vtinam ſemus, ſetis, ſent.
Audiuiſſem, ſes, ſet. Plur. vtinam ſemus, ſetis, ſent.

list.head: God grant I ſhall or will loue hereafter. Future tenſe ſingular, Vtinam,
list.item: Amauero, ris, rit. Plural. vtinam rimus, ritis, rint.
Docuero, ris, rit. Plural. vtinam rimus, ritis, rint.
Legero, ris, rit. Plural. vtinam rimus, ritis, rint.
Audiuero, ris, rit. Plural. vtinam rimus, ritis, rint.

list.head: I may or can loue. Preſent tenſe ſingular,
list.item: Amem, ames, amet. Plur. amemus, ametis, ament,
Doceam, as, at. Pluraliter, amus, atis, ant.
Legam, as, at. Pluraliter, amus, atis, ant.
Audiam, as, at. Pluraliter, amus, atis, ant.

list.head: I might, would, ſhould, ought, or could loue. Preterimperfect tenſe ſingular,
list.item: Amarem, res, ret. Plural. remus, retis, rent.
Docerem, res, ret. Plural. remus, retis, rent.
Legerem, res, ret. Plural. remus, retis, rent.
Audirem, res, ret. Plural. remus, retis, rent.

list.item: Amauerim, ris, rit. Pluraliter, rimus, ritis, rint.

list.item: Amandi, of louing do, in louing. dum, to loue.

Lectum, to reade. Lectu, to be read.
Auditum, to heare Auditu, to be heard.

div.head: Before we decline any Verbes in Or, for ſupplying of many tenſes, lacking in all ſuch Verbes, we muſt learne to decline this Verbe Sum, in this wiſe following.
Sum, es, fui, eſſe: Futurus, To be.
Indicatiue Moode.
div.p: Preſent tenſe ſingular. SVm, I am: es, eſt. Pluraliter, ſumus, eſtis, ſunt.
Preterimperfect tenſe ſingular. Eram, I was: eras, erat. Pluraliter, eramus, eratis, orant.
Preterperfect tenſe ſingul. Fui, I haue been: fuiſti, fuit. Pluraliter, fuimus, fuiſtis, fuerunt vel fuere.
Precerpluperfect tenſe ſingular. Fueram, I had been: fueras, fuerat. Pluraliter, fueramus, fueratis, fuerant.
Future tenſe ſingular. Ero, I ſhall or will be: eris, orit. Pluraliter, erimus, eritis, erunt.

div.head: Imperatiue Moode.
div.p: Preſent tenſe ſingular. Sis, Es, Eſto, be thou. Sir, Eſto, Plur. ſimus, Siris, Eſte, Eſtote Sint, Sunto

div.head: Optatiue Moode.
div.p: Preſent tenſe ſingul. Vtin. Sim, I pray God I be: ſis, ſit. Pluralit, vtinam ſimus, ſitis, ſint.
Preterimperfect tenſe, Vt. Eſſem, Would God I were: eſſes, eſſer. Pluralit. vtinam eſſemus, eſſetis, eſſent.
Preterderfect tenſe ſingul. Vtin. Fuerim, I pray God I haue beeile: fueris, fuerit. Pluralit. vtinam fuerimus, fueritis, fuerint.
Preterpluperfect tenſe ſing. Vtin. Fuiſſem, Would God I had been: fuiſſes fuiſſet. Pluralit. vtinam fuiſſemus, fuiſſetis, fuiſſent.
Future tenſe ſin. Vtin. Fuero, God grant I be hereafter: fueris, fuerit. Pluraliter, vtinam fuerimus, fueritis, fuerint.

div.head: Potentiall Moode.
div.p: Preſent tenſe ſingular. Sim, I may or can be: ſis, ſit. Pluraliter, ſimus, ſitis, ſint.
Preterimperfoct tenſe ſingular. Eſſem, I might or could be: eſſes, eſſet. Pluraliter, eſſemus, eſſetis, eſſent.
Preterperfect tenſe ſingular Fuerim, I might, could, ſhould, or ought to haue bin: fieris, fuerit. Plur. fuerimus, fueritis, fuerint▪
Preterpluperfect tenſe ſingular. Fuiſſem, I might, could, ſhould, or ought to ha • bin: fuiſſes, fuiſſet. Pl. fuiſſemus, fuiſſetis, fuiſſent▪
Future tenſe ſingular. Fuero, I may or can be hereafter: fuertis, fuerit Pluraliter, fuerimus, fueritis, fuerint.

div.head: Subiunctiue Moode.
div.p: Preſent tenſe ſingular. cùm Sim, When I am: ſis, ſit. Plur. cùm ſimus, ſitis, ſint▪
Preterimperfect tenſe ſingular, Cùm. Eſſem, When I was: eſſes, eſſet. Plural. cùm eſſemus, eſſetis, eſſent.
Preterperfect tenſe ſi. Cùm Fuerim, When I haue been: fueris, fuerit. Plur • cùm fuerimus, fueritis, fuerint.
Preterpluperfect tenſae ſin. Cùm. Fuiſſem, When I had been: fuiſſes, fuiſſet. Plur • cùm fuiſſemus, fuiſſetis, fuiſſent.
Future tenſe ſing. Cùm. Fuero, When I ſhall or will be: fueris, fuerit. P • cùm fuerimus, fueritis, fuerint.

div.head: Infinitiue Moode.
div.p: Preſent and preterimpirfect tenſe. Eſſe, to be. Preterperfect & Preterpluperfect tenſe. Fuiſſe, to haue or had been.
Future tenſe. Fore, velfuturum eſſe, To be hereafter.

div.head: Verbes in or, of the foure Coniugations, be declined after theſe Examples.

list.item: AMor, amâ is vel amâre: amatus ſum vel fui, amari: amatus, amandus. To be loued.
Doceot, docêris vel docêre: doctus ſum vel fui, docêri: doctus, docendus. To be taught.
Legor, legĕris vellegĕre: lectus ſum vel fui, legi: lectus, legendus. To be read.
Audior, audîris vel audîre: auditus ſum vel fui, audîri: auditus, audiendus. To be heard.

div.head: Of certaine Verbs going out of Rule, which are declined and formed in maner following.
div.p: POſſum, potes, potui, poſſe, potens: To may or can.
Volo, vis, volui, velle: volendi, volendo, volendum: ſupinis caret, volens: To will, or to be willing.
Nolo, nonvis, nolui, nolle: nolendi, nolendo, nolendum: ſupinis caret, nolens: To nil or to be vnwilling
Malo, mauis, malui, malle: malendi, malendo, ma • lendum: ſupinis caret, malens: To haue rather, or to be more willing.
Edo, edis vel es, edi, edere vel eſſe: edendi, edendo, edendum: eſum, eſu, vel eſtum eſtu: edens, efurus vel eſturus. To eate.
Fio, fis, factus ſum vel fui, fieri: factus, faciendus: To be made, or to be done.
Fero, fers, tuli, ferre: ferendi, ferendo, ferendum: latum, latu: ferens, laturus: To beare or ſuffer.
Feror, ferris vel ferre, latus ſum vel fui, fetri: latus, ferendus: To be borne or ſuffered.

div.head: Indicatiue Moode.

list.head:

• ar,
