Quarum verò ſyllabarum quantitas, Exemplumſiue Authoritas ſub praedictas • ationes non cadit, à Poëtarum vſu, exemplo, atque au
• horitate petenda eſt certiſsima omnium regula. Diſcant ergò pueri obſeruare ex poëtis communes primarum ſyllabarum quantitates, cuius ſortis ſunt:

Britannus, Bithynus, Cacus, Coſyra, Crathis, Quae primam habeant communem. Pachy
• us, palatium, Pelion, criticus, Curetes, Diana, Fide
• ae, Gradivus, hinulus, Pyrene, rubigo, Rutilius, Hy
• men, Italus, liquor, liquidus, Lycas, Orion, rudo, Sy
• haeus, Sycanius, & ſimilia.

div.head: DE MEDIIS SYLLABIS.
div.p:
MEdiae ſyllabae partim eâdem ratione qua primae, partim etiam ex incrementis genitiui, Mediae ſyllabae. at
que coniugationis analogiâ cognoſci poſſunt. Increment • geritiui. De incrementis genitiui nominum polyſyllabarum,
ſuprà in generibus nominum abundè dictum arbitra. mur, vnde petere licebit, ſi quid de hac re haeſitaueris. Caetera frequens lectio & optimorum Poëtarum obſeruatio, facilè ſuppeditabunt.

Coniugationis analogiam ex imbibitis rudimentis pueri didicerunt, Coniugationum analogia nempe A, indicem primae coniugationis, longam eſſe naturâ, praeterquam in do, & eius compoſitis, quando huius ſunt coniugationis: vt, Dămus, circundămus, Dăbis, circundăbis, Dăre, circundăre.

Praeterea ſyllabas rimus & ritis, in praeterito perfecto • modi ſubiunctiui, vbique pro breuibus habendas ani • maduertant, in futuro autem in oratione proſa longas eſſe debere, in carmine verò indifferentes reperiri quéadmodum contendit Aldus: vt, Praeterito Amauérimus, amauéritis: Futuro, Amauerîmus, amauerítis.
Eſt & vbi me • iae ſyllabae variant apud Poëtas, Mediarum ſyllabarum variatio. vt in his quae ſubiunximus: Connubium, Ficedula, Malea, Pharſalia, Batavus, Sidonius, & ſimilia.
Adiectiua in inus Latina, Adiectiua in inus. penultimam producunt: vt, Cland eſtînus, mediaſtînus, parietînus, matutînus, veſpertînus, repentînus.

list.item: Praeter haec ſequentia Diutĭnus, Serotĭnus,
Praeter haec ſequentia Craſtĭnus, Oleagĭnus,
Praeter haec ſequentia Priſtĭnus, Fagĭnus,
Praeter haec ſequentia Perendĭnus, Cedrĭnus,
Praeter haec ſequentia Hornotĭnus, Carbasĭnu •

div.p:
Et reliqua materialia, ſiue à metallorum nominibu • formata in inus, qualia ſunt permulta à Graecis vocibu • deducta in inos: vt, Chryſtallinus, myrrhinus, hyacinth •
nus, adamantinus, &c.
Caetera foeliciùs docebit vſus, & Poëtarum obſernatio, quàm vllae Grammaticorum regulae, quas ſinvllo aut modo aut fine de mediarum ſyllabarum quantitate tradere ſolent.
Quare illis praetermiſsis, advltimarum ſyllabaru • quantitates aperiendasiam accingamur.

div.head: DE VLTIMIS SYLLABIS.
div.p: QVanquam vltimae ſyllabae ipſum literarum numerum, aut aequant, aut etiam ſuperant, Vltimae ſyllabae. non tamen pigebit illas etiam ordine percurrere.

Primùm A finita producuntur: vt, Amā, A. produc. con
• ra, ergä. Excipias pută, ită, quiă. Exceptio. 1.

Item nominatiuos, & omnes caſus in a, cuiuſcun
que
Exceptio. 2. fuerint generis, numeri, aut declinationis, Limitatio. praeter vocatiuos in A, à Graecis in As: vt, ô Aeneā, ô Thomā, & • blativum primae declinationis: vt ab hac Muſā. Numeralia in ginta, A finalem habent communem, ſed frequentiùs longam: vt Trigintā, quadragintā.
In b, d, t, deſinentia, breuia ſunt: vt, ăb, ăd, capŭt. B, D, T, corripiuntur. C. produc. Exceptio. 1. Exceptio. 2.
In c deſinentia, producuntur, vt āc, sīc, & hīc adverbium. Sed tria in c, ſemper contrahuntur: Làc, nĕc, • onëc. Duo ſunt communia: Fac, & Pronomen hic, & • eutrum hoc, modò non ſit ablatiui caſûs.
E finita, breuia ſunt: vt, Marĕ, penĕ, legĕ, ſcribĕ. E. corrip.

Excipiendae ſunt omnes voces quintae inflectionis in • vt, Diē, fidē, vnà cum aduerbiis inde enatis: vt, Exceptio. 1. Ho
• ē, quotidiē, pridiē, poſtridiē, qua rē, qua de rē, ea rē, 〈◊〉 ſiqua ſunt ſimilia. Exceptio. 2. Et ſecundae item perſonae ſingula
• imperatiuorum actiuorum, ſecundae coniugationis: 〈◊〉 Docē, mouē, manē, cauēe.

Producuntur etiam monoſyllaba in E: vt: Mē, tē, ſē, Exceptio. 3. Limitatio
• rter Quĕ, nĕ, vĕ, coniunctiones incliticas.

Quin & aduerbia quoque in e, ab adiectiuis deducta, Exceptio. 4.
• ongum habent: vt, Pulchrē, doctē, valdē pro validē. • ibus accedunt Fermē, forē. Benĕ tamen & malĕ, Limitatio.
• ripituntur omninò.

Poſtremò, quae à Graecis per n ſcribuntur, Exceptio. 5. naturâ • ducuntur, cuiuſcunque fuerint caſûs, generis aut nu
•• i: vt, Lethē, Anchisē, cetē, tempē.

• nita, longa ſunt: vt Dominī, magiſtrī, amarī, I. produc. docerī.
Praeter Mihi, Exceptio. • . tibi, ſibi, vbi, ibi, quae ſunt communia.

Niſi verò & quaſi, Exceptio. 2, 3. corripiuntur. Cuius etiam ſortis ſunt datiui & vocatiui Graecorum, quorum genitivus ſingular • a in Os breue exit: vt,
Huic Palladĭ, Vocat. ô Amaryllĭ.
Huic Phyllidĭ, Vocat. ô Alexĭ.
Huic Minoidi. Vocat. ô Daphnŏ.
L finita, L. corrip. corripiuntur: vt Animăl, Annibă, mĕ, pugĭl, Săl, Exceptio. conſŭl. Praeternīl contractum à nibil, & Sōl. Et Hebraea quaedam in l: vt Michaēl, Gabriē, Ray haēl, Daniēl.
N finita, N. produc. producuntur: vt Paeān, Hymēn, quīn, Xenophōn, nōn, daemōn.
Excipe forsăn, Exceptio. 1. forſităn, ăn, tamĕn, attamĕn, veruntamĕn.
Corripitur & In cum compoſitis: Exceptio. 2. vt, Exĭn, ſubĭn, deĭn, proĭn.
Accedunt his & voces illae, Exceptio. 3. quae per apocopen caſtrantur: vt, Mĕn? Vidĕn? Audĭn? Nemŏn.
Nomina item in en, Exceptio. 4. quorum genitivus ĭnis, correptum habet: vt, Carmĕn, crimĕn, pectĕn, tibicĕ, ĭnis.
Graeea etiam in On, Exceptio. 5. per o parvum, cuiuſcunque fuerint eaſûs: vt, Nominat. Iliŏn, peliŏn. Accuſatiuo Caucasŏn, pylŏn.
Quae dam etiam in In, Exceptio. 6. vt Alexĭn. In yn, vt Ity̆n.
In An quo que à Nominatiuis in A: Exceptio. 7. vt Nominat. Iphigenia, Aegina. Accuſat. Iphigeniăn, Aeginăn.
Nam in An, à nominatiuis in As, producuntur: v • Nominat. Aeneas, Marſyas. Accuſat. Aeneān, Marſyā • .
O finita, O. commun. communia ſunt: vt, Amo, virgo, porrò, do • cendo, legendo, cundo, & aliae gerundij voces in D •
Praeter obliquos in o, Exceptio. 1. qui ſemper producuntur: vt, H • ic Dominō, ſeruō. Ab hoc templō damnō.
Et aduerbia ab adiectiuis deriuata: Exceptio. 2. vt, Tantō, quant • liquidō, falsō, primō, manifeſtō, &c.
Praeter ſedulò, Limitatio. mutuò, erebrò, ſerò, quae ſunt commun •
Caetorùm modŏ & quomodŏ, Exceptior 3. ſemper corripiuntur.
Citò quoque, vt & ambo, duo, ego, atque homo, Exceptio. 4. vix leguntur producta.
Monoſyllabatamen in o, producuntur, vt Do, ſto, Exceptio. 5. vt & ergō, pro cauſa.
Item Graeca per • ; cuiuſcunque fuerint caſûs: Exceptio. 6. vt haec Sapphō, Didō. Huius Androgeō, Apollō. Hunc Athō, Apollō.
R finita corripiuntur: vt, Caeſă, torculăr, pĕr, vĭr, R. corrip. vxŏr, turtŭr.
Cor, ſemel apud Ouidium productum legitur: Exceptio. 1 vt Mōllĕ mĕūm lĕuĭbūs cōr ēſt vĭŏlābĭlĕ tēlīs.
Producuntur etiam Fār, lār, nār, vēr, fūr, cūr. Exceptio. 2.

Pār quo
que cum compoſitis: vt, Compār, impār, diſpār. Exceptio. 3.

Graeca quaedam in er, quae illis in np deſinunt: vt, Aër, Exceptio. 4.
• ratēr, charactēr, aethēr, ſotēr.
Praeter Patĕr & matèr, quae apud Latinos vltimam breuem habent.
S finita, S. pares cum numero vocalium habent terminationes: nempe, As, es, is, os, us.

Primò, as finita producuntur: vt, Amās, musās, As. produc. ma
• eſtās, bonitās.
Praeter Graeca, Exceptio. 1. quorum Genitivus ſingularis in dos exit: vt, Archăs, Pallăs, Genit, Archadŏs, Palladŏs.

Et praeter accuſativos plurales nominum creſcenti
• m: vt, Horos, Heroos: Phyllis, Phyllidos, Exceptio. 2. Accuſatiuo • lurali, Heroăs, Phyllidăs.
Es finita, longa ſunt: vt, Anchisēs, ſedēs, docēs, patrēs. Ex. produc.

Excipiuntur nomina in es, tertiae inflectionis, Exceptio. • . quae p •
• ultimam genitivi creſcentis corripiunt: vt, Milĕs, ſegĕs, iuĕs. Sed ariēs, abiēs, pariēs, Cerēs, & pēs, Limitatio. vnà cum • ompoſitis: vt, Praepēs, b pēs, tripēs, quadrupēs, longa • nt.

Es quo que à ſum, vnà cum compoſitis corripitur: vt, Exceptio. 2.
• otĕs, adĕs, prodĕs, ohĕs.

Quibus penĕs adiungi poteſt, Exceptio. 3. vnà cum neutris ac
nominatiuis plura libus Graecorum: vt Hippomanĕs, cacoëthes, Cyclôpĕs, Naiadĕs.
Is finita, Is. corrip. breuia ſunt: vt, Parĭs, panĭs, triſtĭs, hilarĭs.
Excipe obliquos plura • es in is, Exceptio. 1. qui producuntur: vt, Musīs, mensīs à menſa, dominis, templīs.
Item queīs pro quibus, Exceptio. 2. cum producentibus penultimam genitiui creſcentis; vt, Samnīs, Salamīs. Genitiuo Samnîtis, Salamînis.
Adde huc quae in Eis diphthongum deſinunt, Exceptio. 3. ſiue Graeca, ſiue Latina, cuiuſcunque fuerint numeri aut caſûs: vt, Simoëïs, Pyroëïs, parteīs, omneīs.
Et monoſyllaba item omnia: Exceptio. 4. vt Vīs, līs, praeter ĭs, & quis nominativos, & Bĭs apud Ouidium.

Iſtis accedunt ſecundae perſonae ſingulares verborum in is, Exceptio. 5. quorum ſecundae perſonae plurales deſinunt in îtis, penultimâ productâ, vnà cum futuris ſubiunctiui in ris: vt Audīs, velīs, dederīs. pl. Audîtis, velîtis, dederîtis.
Os finita producuntur: Os. produe. vt, Honōs, nepōs, dominōs, ſeruōs.
Praeter compŏs, Exceptio. impŏs, & ŏs oſsis. Et Graeca per o parvum: vt, Delŏs, Chaŏs, Palladŏs, Phyllidŏs.
Vs finita corripiuntur: Vs. corrip. vt, Famulŭs, regiŭs, tempŭs, amamŭs.
Excipiuntur producentia penultimam genitiui ereſcentis: Exceptio. 1. vt, Salūs, tellūs, Genitivo ſalûtis, tellûris.
Longae ſunt etiam omnes voces quartae inflexionis in us, Exceptio. 2. praeter nominativum & vocativum ſingulares: vt, Huius manūs, hae manūs, has manūs, ô manus.
His accedunt etiam monoſyllaba: Exceptio. 3. vt Crūs, thūs, mūs, ſūs, &c.
Et Graeca item per ous diphthongum, Exceptio. 4. cuiuſcunque fuerint caſus: vt Hic Panthūs, Melampūs. Huius Sapphūs, Cliūs.

p.hi: Atquc pijs cunctis venerandum nomen Iëſūs.

div.p: Poſtremò, produc. u finita producuntur omnia: vt Manū, genū, amatū, diū.

div.head: OMNIVM NOMINVM IN Regulis Generum contentorum tum Heteroclitorum ac Verborum, interpretatio alique.

list.item: ARdo, To hide.
Abſcondo, occulto, To hide.

Abyſſus, immenſa quaedam profunditas im
• en • trabilis. A depth that by ſounding 〈◊〉 cannot b • ſound.
• carnan, gens ex quadam regione 〈◊〉 Graeci • . The people of Acarnania in Greece.
• cer, Arbor. A Maple tree.
• ccerſo, co ad vocandum, vel voco. To go • to call.

• ties, acumen rerum ſecantium, ex
• ercitus inſtructio, oculi lumen. An edge. The array of an army. The ſight of the eye.
• cus, inſtrumentum ſartoris, ac mulieris ornamentum. A needle, or an inſtrument wherewith women did ſet their haire.
• deps, omnis pinguedo, ſiue carnis, ſiue alterius rei. Fatte.
• dipiſcor, aſſequutus ſum. To obtaine.
• doleſeens, iuvenis adultus. A ſtripling from twelue to xxi.
• dor, frumenti genus vel farris. Wheate.
• uena, qui non eſt ciuis, ſed externus. A ſtranger.

• ther, tota coeli ſyderum
que ſubſtantia ac compago. The whole ſubſtance of the Spheres from the fire vnto the extremeſt circuit of heauen.

• equor, marc, pelagus. The ſea, becauſe nothing is more plaine then it: for Acquor doth generally ſignifie a plaine in any parcell of the world. Jt • taken for the aire alſo: as, Aſpice • is ſenos volitātes aequore cygnos. • s, ſpecies m • tallirubro colore. Copper, and becauſe that in olds time money was made of it, Aes, ſometime doth ſignifie money.
Affinis, cognatus. A kinſman by mariage.
Agnoſco, eſt noſcere id, quod nobis olim aut viſum fuit, aut alia quapiam ratione cognitum. To recognize, to knowe a new, or to come to remembrance of.
Ago, facio. To doe.
Agragas, vrbs Sicil. A towne in the Iſla of Sicile, called now Gergenti.
Agricola, qui exercitat tem ruſticam. An husbandman.
Alcyon, aues maritima, hyeme pullos educans. A certaine ſea-birde that lyeth in the ſands, and hatcheth in winter.
Ales, quaelibet auis, aut velox. A bird, or ſwift.
Alnus, genus arboris. An Alder tree.
Alo, nutrio. To nouriſh.
Alter. The other of the two.
Alvus, qua ſordes defluunt. aut luuntur. The paunch, and ſometime the belly without.
Amazones, Scythicae foeminae, co quòd mammis careant. Certaine women of Scythia, ſo named for lacking a dugge.
Ambigo, circumago, circundo. To compaſſe, to doubt.
Amicio, veſtio. To cloath.
Amnis, fluvius. A riuer.
Anas, auis in aquis degens. A Ducke, or a drake.
Ango, crucio, premo, vexo. To trouble and vexe.
Anguis, ſerpens in aquis degens. A drie or a watrie ſnake.
Animus, conſilij principium. The mind
Anna, nomen mulieris. Anne.
A •… , aſſentior. To aſſent & agree 〈◊〉

Annus, tempus 365 •… die •… & •…
arum. A •… are.
Anus, verule. A noble wife.

Applico, & iungo, & aduenio. To app •… , or to arriue.

Arpoſſo, voco, & accuſo. To call, or to accuſe, or to goe to accuſe.

Arces, or Arcadia populus. The 〈◊〉
ple or Arcadia.

Arctus, 〈◊〉 , quam noſtri ſoprentri •… o 〈◊〉

A pound of 〈…〉 of any thing.
Aſſec •… , qui continue & ſ •… quid ſequitur. A page, or 〈◊〉 continuall 〈◊〉 .

A • ſter, ventus •… ans a meridi • . The ſouth winds.
A •… , qui vel quae aliquod opus facit. The worker or doer of any thing, man or woman.

Axis, diametros mundi, & dicitur lignum •… res, circa quod rora curcus vertitur. An Ax •…
〈…〉 , the ſtraight line that may be imagined from the one pole to the other pole.

list.head: B
list.item: BAcchanalia, Dyonisia • . Bacchi fe •• a. The feast of Bacchus.

Bacchar, herbaradieis odoratae
〈◊◊〉 , that the Frenchmen call our Ladies gloves
Bacchus, deus vini. The drunken god, the god of wine.
Baculus, ba • illus, & baculum. & hinc bacillum, ſcipio 〈◊◊〉
Balneum, locus publicus vel priuatus, in quo aut ſanitatis, aut abſtergendarum ſordium cauſa lauamur. A bath.
Barathrum, erat locus profundior Athenis, putei modo vel forma. A certaine 〈◊〉 by Athens. Now it is taken for bell It i • alſo the hole where any water extret • and falleth into the earth.
Barbiton, inſtrumentum muſicum quod pulſatur plectro vel calamo. The Lute, or any like that is played on with a quill. It is alſo Barbitos, both maſculine and feminine.
Bellaria, cibi ſecundae menſae. Iuncats
Bes, vnciae octo. Eight ounces.
Bibo, potum haurio, humorem attraho. To drinke.
Bidens, inſtrumentum duorum dentium, vel 〈◊〉 . Any instrument with two teeth, or a ſheepe of two teeth, in the feminine gender.
Biſrons, habens dua frontes. Hee or ſhee that hath a face before, an other behinde.

Bili • humoris genus, It is with this word arra, melancholie, and with
• laua, chaler and beeing uſed alone,is the ſame ſenſe that Cholera is after Cor. Celſus. See Cholera
Bombix, vermis & pre materia ſumitur. A ſilk, orme, or ſilke
Bos, nora eſt ſignificatio. An One, Bull, or Cow
Britannia, Inſula quam nunc Angli, & Scori incolunt. The Iſle which is inhabited of Engliſh men and Scotiſh men, and is called Britannia maior.
Britannia minor. Is Britain in France.
Bubo, auis nomen, à bouis mugitu. An Owle.
Buc • phalus, nomen equi Alexandri Magni. Alexander the great his horſe.
Byſſus, tenuiſſimi lini genus. A moſt fine ſort of fine flaxe, whereof a moſt precious kind of linnen cloath is made, It may be taken for ſilke alſo.

list.head: C
list.item: CAcoethes, malus mos. An euill cuſtome, or a bile hard to be cured.
Cadauer, corpus mortu • . A carkaſſe.
Cado, corruo, praecipitor, vellabor. To ſall, and ſometime to happen, to chance.

Caedo, percutio, ferio, verbero. To ſtrike, or to beate and ſometime to cut or to loppe, or to prune trees, ſometime to kill, ſometime to ſacrifice, and ſometime to breake, as caedere ianuam ſaxis, inſtare ferro.
Caello, percutio, aut frango, To ſmite or to breake, antiquum verbum. The Compounds whereof be in vſe onely. Cello is read alſo without a dip •• hong.
Caelum vel coelum, extrema mundi detenninatio cum ſphaeris quas ambit ad elementum ignis. Heauen, or with a difference any of the ſpheres. It ſignifieth w • ather alſo.
Calco, pede comprimo. To tread vpon, and by a tranſlation vnto the mind, to deſpiſe and ſat naught by.
Calendae, dies primus cuiuſque menſis. The firſt day of euery moneth.
Calco, ferueo, callidus ſu • h. To be hot, or to glow.
Callis, via perdurata, id eſt, via trita. A path way.
Caluo, decipio, fruſtror. To deceiuc, to beguile, and to trompe.
Calx, pes imus, & pro cuiuſuis rei ſine ponitur, vel pro materia qua lapides in muro conglutinantur. An he • le, or laſt end of a race, or lime.
Cambio, commuto. To exchange • & of the old writers it is taken for to fight.
Canalis, per quod aqua confluit in viis lapide ſtratis. A chanell.
Cancelli, ligna inter ſe modicis interuallis in tranſuerſum inſtar re • is ••• icem annexa. A lattic • , or the lifts of a game place or 〈◊〉 a ſ •• ctacle.
Canis, animal latrabile, & piſcis marinus, & ſignum coeleſte. A dog ge or a dogge fiſh, and a ſtarre or ſigne in the firament, called Canis.
Cano. To ſing, to indite poetically, to play vpon inſtruments. Sometime it is topraiſe or to • ropheſie.
Capeſſo, capio, ſiue ad capiendum co. To take or to goe to take, and ſometime recipio me, to goe: as, Nunc pergam horae imperium exequi, & me domum capeſſam.

Capio. To take to delighs, to deceiue, to chuſe, to abide and ſuffer: as, Capio dolores. To hold or containe. To inuade & catch: as. Nauem cepimus To •• flame with loue. And is lightly of ſuch ſignification as the ablatiue is that commeth with it.
Capiſtrū, capitis vinculum, adhibitū ne animalia aufugiant. An halter.
Capital, quod olim ſacerdotes geſtabant in capite. An ornament that the Nunnes were wont to beare vpon their heads.
Capra, animal à carpendis virgultis dictum. A goat.
Car, aliquis ex Caria. A man of Caria.
Cardo, quo ianua mouetur. An booke or hinge.
Careo, eſt rem deſideratam non habere. To lacke, or to be withou • and ſpecially ſuch a thing as once we had.
Carex, herba acuta duriſſima. Sedge.
Caro, quod anima careat, non ſolum do animalibus, ſed etiam de piſeibus & fructibus. The meate of any thing, but moſt commonly fleſh.

Carpo, decerpo. To crop, to bite off, nottle, or to gather. It is alſo to leaſe, or to chooſeout, and ſometime to tant or rebuke. Carpere viam, is to begin to iourney. Carpere vitales auras, Carpere lanam, to teiſe wooll. Carpere linum, To hatchell flaxe. Carpere cibum. To eat.
Caſtra, locus in quo milites tentoria fixerunt. The • ampe, the pamlions, or the armie.
Caſſis, reticulum, & pro galea foemini: eſt caſſis, dis, & haec caſſida. A net, or an holm • t in the feminine gender.
Cato, nomen viri. Acertain Romans name.

Caueo, diligentiam adhibeo, prouideo, conſulo, proſpicio ne aliquid praeter ſpem eueniat. To beware, or to be wary and heedſull. Cauere is alſo to put in aſſurance, and to ſaue harmoleſſe by caution or ſureties.
Caulis, in herbis dicitur ipſum robur fiue ſtipes. A ſtalke.

Cedo. To g •• to place, to depart or go away
• edrus, arbor ingens & procera. A • Cedar tr • e.
• ello. See Caello.

• enſeo, exiſtimo, puto, arbitror. To • deeme, to iudge, to ſuppoſe, to thinke, to • tell ones minde. Some take it for to be angry. Cenſeri, is alſo to be in books • of ſubſidies, & to be task • d or valued
• entum. An hundred.
• entuſſis, centum librarum. An hundred pound.
• era, illud quod melle ex fauis expreſſo remanet. Waxe.

•• rno, video. To ſee. By tranſlation to perceiue and vnderſtand. Sometime to decree and appoint. To fiſt, to range or bolt, to ſeuer and part, to fight, to goe vnto: as, Cernere haereditatem. • ctus, piſcis maximus. A whale.
• holera, eſt ventriculi immodicaperturbatio, ſupra & infra per vomitum facta. The Collike. It is alſo cholor the hot and dry humour.
• cer, genus leguminis. A certaine Indian peaſe.
• eo, turbo, commoueo. To trouble, to ſhake and ſtirre, and ſometime for Cio, it is to call.
• nis, vel ciner, puluis. Aſhes. Cinis eſt auis, quam alio nomine alaudam dicimus. A Larke.
• audo, obſtruo, obſero. To ſhut, or •• loſe, to make faſt, to ſtoppe or to ſtay, not to ſuffer to paſſe further: as, Ecce maris magna claudit nos obice pontus.
• ivus, locus molliter arduus, & pro colle ponitur. A banke ariſing, and it is uſed for a little hill.

• unis, natium tumor. The buttocke.
• uo, ſplendeo. To thine, to gliſter: ſometime to fight.
• ypcus & Clypeum, ſcuta maiora & propriè peditum. A buckler.

• elum. A grauing toole, the skic that • is, as much of the world as is aboue the element of fire, which is called aether, or Quintum elementum. Coelum alſo ſometime is taken for the atre, as, In hoc coelo qui dicitur aer.
Coeno, coenam ſumo. To ſuppe, or to take ſupper.
Coepio, pro incipio, antiquum eſt. To begin.

Cognoſco, noſco cos qui priùs incogniti crant. To know that which we knowe not before, ſometime d • ligently and attentiuely to conſider, or to vnderſtand, to ſearch by an inquiry, and to ſit in iudgement.
Collis, monticulus. An hillock.

Colo, adoro, veneror. To honour, or worſhippe with prayer, ſometime to make much of, to exerciſe, to inhabite, to loue: & vitam colere, is to lead a life, ſometime to plowe or till the ground, ſometime to decke and trim.
Colus, inſtrumentum quod penſa continet. A diſtaffe or ſpindle.
Comes, comitans aut ſequens. A companion by the way, • uherman or woman.
Comminiſcor, fingo, excogito. To imagine, to faine, to inuent and deuiſe, to aſſay, to bring a man to the beleeſe of that that is not.
Como, comam compono. To keame, to dreſſe the buſh with a combe, or to decke and adorne.
Compago, compactio, & coniunctio. Aiornt.
Compedes, vineuli genus. A payre of fetters or giues.
Congrus, conger, genus piſcis. A Congre.
Coniux, maritus vel vxor. A husband or wife.

Coque, cibum vſui aptum reddo. To dreſſe meate, to play the Cooke, to prepare and goe about: as, Bellum coquere. To vexe and trouble, as Coquit me cura. To concoct, to
bring our nutriment vnto a naturall ſoment or iuyes.

Conſulo. To aske counſell with an accuſatiue: to giue counſell, or prouide for, with a datiue: to take in good worth, with a genitiue. Sometime it is to fit in counſell, and to deliberate, but vſed plurally, as, conſulunt Senatores.
Cor, praecipuum inter viſcera, & vitae ſedes, & arterearum, ac caloris natiui, quo animal regitur, quaſi ſons quidam & domicilium. The heart, and ſometime it is vſed for the mind.

Cornus, vel Cornum, aut Cornu, munimentum capitis quorundam animalium. An born • . By tr • uſlation the turning of riuers be called Cor
• ua. It ſignifieth alſo the w • ng of an army, and the end of any thing.
Cornus, arbor ramos habens duritia & rigiditate cornibus ſimiles, fructumcirca ſolſtitium ferens, primo candidum, poſtea ſanguineum. A certaine tree vnkno • ne among vs.
Coſtus, radix magni odoris. A ſhrub gr ••• ing in Arabia, Iu • y, and Syria, 〈◊〉 a roote of very ir •• r • n • ſanour, the which antiquitie burned to their gods, as they did frankincenſe.
Coxendix, coxarum vertex, quo femora vertuntur. The hippe.
Crater vel cratera, vas amplum, cui vinum aut oleum imponimus. A Goblet or ſtandi • g 〈◊〉 .
Crepo, ſouo. To cracke. Sometime to complain, lam • nt, and accuſ ••• , Quis poſt vina grauem pauperiem crepat▪
Crepundia, prima munuſeu 'a quae pueris dantur. All manneroſthings that are giu • nchildren in their in ſanc • e: as Corrals, ſ •• d ••• hands, daggers, timbrels▪ and ſuch like.
Cr • ta inſula eſt. The Jſle called Caudy.
Crey, Cretenſis. A man of Candie.
Crinis, capillus. Haire.
Cryſtallus, glacies ex gelu vehementer concreta. Cryſtall.
Crus, pars a genibus vſque ad inferiorem pedem. A Logge
Conditor, qui aliquid facit. A maker or builder.
Corbis, vas ex viminibus factum, A baskes.
Cubo, iacco. To lie, and ſometime to be ſicke in bed.
Cueumis. Acueumer, the which is alſo called in Latiue Cue • mer.
Cumbo. The ſame that Cubo is.
Culex, ve mieulus alatus. A guat.
Cunabula, cunae. A cradle.
Cunae, eunabula, idem.
Cupio, opto, deſidero. Tocouet, to deſire, to luſt for: and ſometime with • d • tine to ſauour.
Cupreſſus, arboris nomen. A Cypre tree.
Cures, oppidi nomen. A townes name •
Cureulio, animal parvum, frumentum corrodens. A Weſell.
Curro, celeriter co, gradum praecipito, intenta celeritate viam qua • voro. Torun, and ſometime to ſtom • that is, to runne as riuers doe.
Cuſp • s, aeurto • pars haſtae. The poi • of a ſpeare, • ike, partizan, or any oth • like.
Cuſtos, qui vel quae rem aliquā tue tur & curat. Akeeper, man or woma •
Cyprus, inſula diues. Cypres the Iſ ••

list.head: D
list.item: DAma, animal timidum. A Buck or a Doe.
Damno, damno afficio, vel conde • no. To dammage, or to condemne.
Dedo, in perpetu • m do, vel totuſubdo, ſiue in manus & arbit • iu • do. Toyeeld.

Defrutum, a deferendo, vinum dee •
ctum ad medium partem. W ••
ſodden to the halfe.
Dego, ago. To line.
Deleo, expun • o, propriè lineas aut regulas. To put out, and to cancell.
Dehcium, oblectamentum, quod nobis voluptati eſt. The thing wherein 〈◊〉 take pleaſure.
Delplun, vel delphinus, vel delphis, piſeis maris, & ſignum c • eleſte. A Dolphin.

Demo, aufero. To pullan ay, and to ex
•• p • .
Den, notum eſt, per ſimilitudinem, cap • tur pro omni, quo aliquid teri poteſt. A tooth.
Depango, defigo. To ſaſten down, and to plant.
Deſidia, ignauiae vitium. Sloth fulneſſe
Dieo, loquor, nomi • o. To ſpeake, or to call.
Dies, tempus viginti quatuor horarum. A day.
Diſſiteor, iuſicias eo, nego. To denie.
Dig • edior, diſeedo. To got from.
Diligo, amo. To loue.
Dil • o, aqua vel quouis humore aliquid purgo. To purge with w • ſling.
Diphthongu • , vnus duaſ •• voe • lium ſonus. A double ſound. Adiphthong.
Diptoton, now • en flexum duobus in eaſibus quib • ſcunque. A Nowne declined with two eaſes whatſoeuer.
Dindimus, iugum, montis Ph • ygia • , Idar matri deûm dicarum. The top of Ida, the hill by Troy.
Dirae, imprecationes, execrationes, & inferorum furiae. Curſes, banuing • , and the furies of hell.
Diſco, capio doctrinam. To learne.
Diſpeſco, ſeparo, dirimo. To ſeuer.
Diſpliceo. To diſpleaſe.
Ditionis, imper • i, dominii. Of my right and title. We need not ſcrupulouſly to teſuſe Ditio the Nominatiue.
Diuido, partior. To d • uide.
Diuitiae, opes, amplae fortunae. Riche •

Do, dono.
• o g ••• .
Doceo, • licuius rei cognitionem alteri trado. To teach, and ſometime to ſhea, and to declare, to warne, and to aſcertaine.
Dodrans, vnciae nouem. Nine oun • es.
Doleo, triſtis ſum. To be ſorrowfull.
Domo, manſectum facio. Totame.
Domus, adilicium ad habitandum factum. Anhouſe.
Duco, notum eſt. To lead, to marry, to account.
Duleedo, ſuauitas. Sweetneſſe.
Dux, qui vel quae ducit aliquem. A guide man or woman.

list.head: E
list.item: ECquis. Whether any.
Edo, comedo. To eat.

Edo .i. mitto, & quaſi extrudo. To ſet out, and to ovulgate: and ſome. time to exhibit, and ſho •• as Edere ſpectacula Edere animam, is to die. The ſigniſication of it in all other phraſes, may bereduced to the firſt ſignification.
Edoceo, diligenter docco. Throughly or perſictly to reach.
Effara, ſunt vltimae precationes augurum, poſt finem auſpiciorum extra vrbem dictae. The prayers that Soothſayers ſaid, after notice taken of birds flying, before they entered the Citie.
Egeo, careo. To neede.
Elephas, clephantus, animal fama notum. An Elephant.
Elis, ciuitas Arcadiae. A citie in Arcadia, or a countrey in P • lopouneſus.
Emineo, prae aliis appareo, vel excello. To appeare before others, and to paſſe them.
Emo, comparo, mercor. To buy.
Enſis, gladrus. A ſword.
Epaſco. To eate vp, to conſume with feeding, and to leaue nothing.
Epulum, quaſi edipulum, eſt celebre conviuium. Abanquet or ſeaſt.
Eques, homo equo inſidens, An horſeman, or he or ſhe that rideth.
Eremus, locus deſertus. A deſart, or wildernes.
Eripio, extra rapio. To pull out.
Eſurio, famem patior. To hunger.
Edentus, euentum, quod caſu aut fortuna nobis euenit. Hap, or that that commeth to paſſe.
Excludo, extra claudo. To ſhut out.
Excubiae, vigiliae diurnae & nocturnae. VVatchings and warding • .
Exculpo, perfectè ſcalpo, vel ſcalpendo conſicio. To carue, to graue, to cut out, to ſcratch out: as, Oculum exculpero. To wrest, or wring out: as Verum excalpere.
Excurro, extra curro, vel praecurro. To run out, or to outrun before, to amount to a great deale, to make an out rode, or an excurſion.
Exequiae, funebre officium. The ceremontes of the buriall.
Excuſo, extra culpā reddo. To excuſe.
Excutio, eiicio, emitto. To ſmite out.
Exlex, ſine lege viuens. A lawleſſe man or woman.
Expergiſcor, cuigilo. To • ake.
Experior, tento, vel tentor. To prooue or be prooued.
Explico, extendo, & declaro. To ſtretch out, and to declare.
Exta, propriè cor, • ecur, & pulmo dicuntur. The entrailes.
Extorris, exul. A baniſhed mā or womā.
Exul, qui vel quae exulat, A baniſhed man or woman.
Exuo, exoluo, denudo. To put off, to vncloth.
Exuviae, ab exuendo. The things that we put off.

list.head: F
list.item: FAcies. A face.
Facio, aliquid ago. To make.
Faceſſo, facio, vel co ad faciendum. To make, or to goe to make.
Fallo, decipio. To deceiue.
Fames, edendi cupiditas. Hunger.
Far. Once a generall word for any kinde of graine or corne: as, Triticeum far, hordeaceum, ſiligineum, &c. But now it ſignifieth one certaine kinde, called Ador, which it bread corn • .
Farcio, ſaturo, impleo, pinguefacio, ſagino. To ſtuffe, to fill, to ſatisfie, & make ſat
Fas, pium, religioſum, & dignum factu. Lawfull, right, godly, and worth the doing.
Faſcis, lignorum, aut alicuius reicongeries. A faggot.

Faſti, libri in quibus totius anni res populi Romani ſcriptae continebantur, & cauſae feſtiuitatum explicabantur. A Regiſter for the order of things, for the whole yeare Faſtidies, were dayes wherein the Iudge • might giue ſentence without offence of the gods, with theſe three ſolemne words of the law, Do, dico, addico. Nefaſti dies, were their cōtrary dities.
Fateor, annuo, concedo. To grant and aſſent vnto.
Fatiſco, deſicio, aut defatigor. Abundartly to g • pe.
Fatiſcor, feſſus ſum. To be weary, to faint, and to be weake.
Faueo, rectè alicui opto. To ſauour.
Fel, purgamentum ſanguinis. The gal.
Feriae, dies ceſſationum ab opere. Holy daies, or time of paſtime vſed.
Ferio, percutio. To strike.
Fero. To beare, or to ſuffer, to lead, or tel, to giue, to couet, to aduance, to bring forth, to haue, to take away, to obtaine, to aske aduice: as, Pompeius tulit ad • populum.
Ferueo, valde caleo. To be hot.
Ferueſco, caleſco. To waxe hot.

Ficus, arbor vel morbus. A fig tree, 〈◊〉
a certain bile riſing in the fundament.
Fides, conſtantia in omnibus rebus. Faith and truth.
Fido, fiduciam & ſpem habeo. To haue truſt.
Figo. To faſten, to plant, to ſmite with arrow or ſuch like.
Filum, illud ſubtile quod ex lino lanáne trahendo ducitur. A thred.
Filix, herba ſine caule, ſine flore, ſine ſemine. Ferne, whereof there be two kinds, as in Herbaries you ſhall ſee.
Funus, laetamen & excrementa animalium, quibus agri ſtercorantur. Dung. It is alſo Fimum, in the neuter gender,
Findo, diſſeco, diſſindo. To cleaue.
Fingo, formo. To faſhion.
Finis, extremitas, ſiue terminus in vnaquaque re. An ende.
Fio, eſſicior. To be made.
Flaueo, flavus ſum. To be yellow.
Flecto, inclino, voluo, duco, moneo. To bow, to mooue & to cauſe to follow
• leo, lachrymor. To weepe.
• lo, ſpiro. To blowe.
• o • , dictus qui ex arboribus vel herbis colligitur. A flower.
• uo, decurro, propriè vt liquores. To flowe.
• dio, terram cruo. To digge.
• llis, inſtrumentum quo attrahitur atque emittitur ventus. A payre of bellowes.
• us, ſcatebra. A well.
•• ceps, inſtrumentum quo tenetur aliquid. A paire of tōngs.

•• fex, inſtrumentum ſarto rum, quo aliquid ſcinditur. A paire of ſciſcers
•• s, fortuna, caſus. Happe.

• rum, à ferendo, quià lites & vena
• ia illuc feruntur. The iudicial place, and then it is named Forum iudiciale: or the market place, and is called, Forum venale.
• ngo, rumpo, deſtruo, To breake.
Frenum, vel fraenum, inſtrumentum quo equum inſeſſor coercet. A bridle.
Frico, ſcalpo. To rubbe.
Frigeo, frigidus ſum. To be colde.
Frugi, indeclinabile omnis generis, vtilis, neceſſarius, frugalis. Good, profitable and thrifty.
Frugis, eius quod ex terrae fructu in alimoniam vertimus. Of corne or pulſe. Some make the Nominatiue hereof, Fruges, and ſome Frux: the formoſt is not to be miſliked.
Fruor, delectationem, & fructum capio, & alor. To take pleaſure, or fruit and profit of, and to be fed.
Fundo, liquefacio, vel liquidum ſpargo. To melt, or to powre.
Fugio, vito, eurrendo relinquor. To flee from, to auoide.
Fulcio, ſuſtineo, munio. To vnderprop and to ſhort.
Fuga, fugiendi actus. Flying, or running away.
Funis, reſtis. A rope.
Fur, qui vel quae alteri ſubtrahit. A man or woman theefe.
Furfur, purgamentum farinae. Braune or ſcurfe.
Furo, inſanio. To be madde.
Fuſtis, baculus. A club.

list.head: G
list.item: GAbii, Volſcorum vrbs. A town in Italie, ſeuenty miles from Rome.
Gallia, Europae pars, ſita intra Pirenaeos montes, inter Hiſpaniam, Germaniamque, & duo Maria, Oceanum Britannicum, & mare noſtrum, France.
Garamas, Lybiae incola. A certaine inhabitant of Affricke.
Gargarus, vnus ex collibus montis Idae. A very high top of the hill Ida. There is alſo a towne of that name at the foot of the ſame hill.
Gaudeo, laetor. To reioyce.
Gelu, propriè glacies. Froſt, or Jſe.
Genu, curuatura qua crus & femur connectuntur. A knee.
Gero, porto. To beare.
Gibbus, & gibber, ſolidus in dorſo tumor. A iub, or a bunch.
Gigas, vir altiſſimae ſtaturae. A Gyant.
Gigno, genero. To beget.
Gingiber, herba in Arabia naſcens. Ginger.
Gliſco, Creſen, augeor, invaleſco. To increaſe and growe, to waxe ſtrong, to waxe fat, or much to deſire, and ſore to couet.
Glis, animal muri ſimile. A dormouſe.
Gluten, glutinum, aut colla. Glue.
Gorgon, nomen mulieris. A certaine terrible woman.
Gradior, co, incedo, progredior. To goe.
G • aecia. The countrey of Greece, a great peice of Europe which is now vnder the Turke.
Graiugena, Graecus. A Grecian borne.
Grando, gutta aquae in aere congelata. Hayle.
Grates, gratiae relatae pro accepto beneficio. Thanks.
Grex, pecudum multitudo. A flock.
Gryps, animal pennatum, omni ex parte leoni ſimile. A Gryffon.
Groſſus, ficus abortiua, quae non matureſcit. A rath ripe figge.
Gruo, vt grues gruere dicuntur. To crie like a Crane.
Grus, auis nota. A Crane.
Gummi, liquor glutinoſus ex arboribus reſudans. Gummi.
Gurgulio, pars gutturis à naribus ad pulmonem, vel animal. The weſand, or a VVeſell.

list.head: H
list.item: HAbeo, poſſideo, teneo. To haue.
Haereo, arctè alicui rei infigor. To cleaue vnto.
Haeres, qui ſuceedit in haereditatem alterius. An heire.
Hale • , piſcis qui ſola aqua nutritur. A herring.
Heros, vir illuſtris, & nobilis. A noble man, a man of great excellencie in worthy facts, and therein more like a god then a man.
Heſperus, ſerotina ſtella. The euening ſtarre.
Heteroclitum, nomen ſecus quam declinationum canones poſcunt flexum. A word declared otherwiſe then the bare rules of the declenſions do require.
Haurio, extraho humorem, & educo ex profundo aliquo loco. To draw.
Hilaris, vel hilarus, iucundus, laetus, Merry.

Hippomanes, virus ab equa collectum, vel caruncula in fronte pulli • equini, hominē ad inſaniam redigens. Poiſon to procure loue withall, or a little peice of fleſh growing in the colts forehead when it is first foaled.
Hirundo, auis notiſſima. A ſwallow.
Hiſtrix, animal ex herinaciorum genere. A poreupike.
Homo, notae ſigniſicationis. A man or woman.
Honor, vel honos, eſt reuerenti • quam alicui exhibemus in virtuta teſtimonium. Honour, worſhippe.
Hordeum, ab horrore, quoniam ho • deo quam frumento ariſta 〈◊〉 mordacior. Barley.
Hoſpes, qui vel quae ad hoſpitium recipit, aut recipitur, & capitur pr • peregrino. An hoſt, or an hoſteſſe, a gueſt, man or woman.
Hoſtis, inimicus vel peregrinus. A • enemie.
Huber, fertilis, abundans, & mam • pecoris & hominis. Plentifull, a dugge, or the vdder of ary beast.
Humus, terra humefacta. The ground.
Hydrops, aqua intercus. The dropſie.
Hyems, bruma. VVinter.

list.head: I
list.item: IAceo, decumbo. To lie.

Iacio, emitto, ac vi impello. To caſt, to whurle, to lay: as, Iacere fundamentum, or by tranſlation it is to make a beginning: Iacio, is ſometime to ſpread abroad by rumour, and ſometime to obiect againſt one with an accuſatiue, with this Prepoſition, in.
Iaſpis, lapis precioſus. A green precious ſtone, whereof there bee diuerſe kinds and degrees of diuers colours.
Ico, ferio, percutio. To ſtrike, to ſmite, as Icere colaphum. Iccre foedus, is to ſtrike vp a bargaine.
Icon, imago. An Image.
Ida, mons altiſſimus Troici ſoli. An hill in the countrey of Troy.
Idus, dies qui diuidunt menſem. Jn March, May, Iune, and October, it is the fifteenth day, in the rest the thirteenth.
Iecur, hepar. The li • er.
Ignis, vnum ex quatuor elementis. Fire.
Illex, qui ſine lege viuit. A law leſſe body, man or woman.
Imber, agmen aquarum largius ex nubibus effuſum. A ſhower.
Imbrex, canalis, vel tegul a curua & obtorta, per quam imber defluit. A gutter tyle.
Immineo, inſto. To hang ouer.
Impetis, violentiae, inuaſionis. Of violence and boyſterouſnes.
Inceſſo, accuſo, impero. To accuſe, to prouoke, to reuile, to inuade and enter into.
Incido, ferio, ſeco. To cut, to graue in.
Incido, in aliquid, vel ſuper aliquid cado. To fall into by hap, to runn into: as, Incidi in errorem. And ſometime to happen or chance.
Incipio, inchoo. To begin, to take in hand, to enterpriſe.
Inculco, eadem ſaepius iterando ingero. Often to repeate.
Indo, impono. To put in.
Indoles, facilis ſignificatio futurae probitatis. Towardneſſe or likely diſpoſition.
Indulgeo, obſequor. To ſet much by, and to giue to.
Induciae, pax in paucos dies. A truce.
Inermus, vel inermis, qui armatus non eſt. Ʋnarmed.
Infans, homo per aetatem nondum ſciens fari. A babe.
Inferiae, ſacrificia quae inferis ſolvuntur. Sacrifice done vnto spirits in h • l. Hereof Inferias facere, is, Manes ſacrificiis placare, that is, To colobrate Obites and Obſequies.
Inficias, negationem, ſe vel debere quod actor poſcit, vel commiſiſſe quod accuſator obiicit. A deniall: and it followeth onely the Ʋerbe Eo.
Inſicio, intingo, vitio, ceu maculo. To die, or to infect.
Ingruo, inuado, impetum facio. To giue an on ſet, and to inuade.
Iniuſſu, abſque authoritate, & temere ſine iuſſione. VVithout bidding.
Iraſcor, ira ſtimulor. To be angrie.
Iſmarus, mons Thraciae, aſper & incultus ex vna parte, ex alia fertilis vinetis & oliuetis. A certaine hill in Thracia ſo named.
Inſidiae, doloſa expectatio ad hominem aggrediend • m, fallacia. A lying in wait for, or a deceit.
Inſtar, ſignificat vel ſimilitudinem, vel aequiparationem & menſuram. Like, or as bigge, or the image.
Intelligo, capio. To vnderſtand.

Interpres, qui authores declarat, aut aliquid ex lingua inlinguam tranſfert. An interpreter, manor woman,
or a tranſlatour.
Inuidia, mocror ex aliena proſperitate. Enuy, ſorrowe for an other mans welfare, or els the euill will & ſpight of a man.
Iocus, eſt quidam lepor & feſtiuitas in verbis. A merry ſcoffe.
Iter, itio, actus cundi. A iourney.
Iubar, ſol, vel ipſius ſplendor. The Sun beame.
Iubeo, impero. To command.
Iudex, qui vel quae iudicat. A iudge, he or ſhe.

Iugeris, agri tantum quantum ab vno pari aut iugo. boum vno die arari poteſt. Plinius. VVe call it an Acre. The authors doe vary in the meaſure of it. For the commoditie of the Nominatiue and other caſes, we may vſe Iugerum.
Iungo, copulo, & quaſi in vnum ago. To ioyne.

Iugum, vertex, ſiue cacumen montis. The top of an hill. It is alſo a yoke, or a yoke of oxen, that is, a couple. By a metaphor it is a ſcruitude, or a bondage. It is alſo a weauers beame, or a payre of gallones, ſuch as for ignominie the • Romanes went vnder. Tribus haſtis iugum fit, humi ſixis duabus, ſuperque • as tranſuerſa vna deligata
Iuno, dea, Iouis vxor. The goddeſſe, Iupiters wife.
Iuro, iuramentum facio. To ſweare.
Ius, quod natura, aut ciuitas, aut gens iubet, & liquor corum quae coquuntur. The law and right, and the broth of any thing ſodden Iuſta.
Iuſſu, imperio, iuſſione. By commandement.
Iuſta, idem quod exequiae.
Iuſtitium, iuris dicendi intermiſſio. No Terme.
Iuvenis, qui adoleſcentium exceſſit aetatem. One come to mans age.
Iuventus, aetas iuvenilis. Mans ſtate.
Iuvo, auxilium do. To helpe.

list.head: L
list.item: LAbes, hiatus, macula, dedecus. A great chap, a spot, a diſhonour, or reproach.
Labor, vel labos, opera, defatigatio. Laborer and toyle, paines taking, ſometime it is miſery, calamity, perill, danger, trauell.
Lac, ſuccus maternus, quo animalia nutriuntur. Milke.
Laceſſo, vexo, incito, prouoco. To trouble, to prouoke.
Lacio, in fraudem duco. To allure, or to entice.
Lactes, gracilliora inteſtina. The ſmall guts.
Lacto, lac emitto, vel per blanditias decipio. To giue milke, or to deceiue.
Lacus, locus profundus cum aquis perpetuis ibidem natis, qui efficit riuos. A lake, a weare, or a mire.
Laedo, verbo factóue aliquem offendo. To hurt.
Laelaps, nomen cuinſdam ē canibus Actaeonis. One of Acteons dogges, called Laelaps for ſpeedie furiouſnes. For Laelaps ſi • n • fieth a whirlewinde, a tempeſt, and a ſtorme.
Lambo, lingua lingo. To licke.
Lampas, ignis aut ſolis ſplendor. A fire, or the brightnes of the Sunne, or a lampe.
Laniſta, qui domi gladiatores docer, & populo vendit. A maſter of defence.
Laquear, pars ſuperior cubiculi parum conuexa. A vaulted roofe of a parlour.

Laſer, herba quaedam, & ſuccus qui ex culmo laſcrpitii exudat. The herbe out of the which commeth the iuyce that the Apothecaries do cal Aſ •
dulcis, and Belzoe, or Belzoin, the common people called it Beniamin.
Lavo, aqua purgo. To waſh.
Lateo, abſcondor, non compareo. To lurke, or to be hidden.
Laurus, genus arboris. A bay tree.
Lebes, vas aeneum. A caldron, or a pan
Lecythus, ampulla olearia. A boxe for oyle and ointment. It is taken alſo for eloquence in writing.
Lego, notum eſt. To reade.
Lemures, laruae nocturnae, & terrificationes imaginum. Hobgoblins, or night sprights.
Leo, animal ferox. A lyon.
Leo, imprimo, formo. To imprint, to forme. Abuſivum.
Lethum, mors, interitus, Death.
Liberi, pignora. Children. One ſonne, or one daughter may be called Liberi, and ſo may nephewes and their ſucceſſours.
Libet, placet. It pleaſeth.
Libs, ventus Aphricus. The Southwest winde, by west.
Licet, fas eſt. It is lawfull.
Lichen, herba vel graniſſimum morbigenus. Liuerwort, the Apothecaries call it Hepatica. It is alſo a kind of leprie, called a ſauce fleame, called in Latine Impetigo.
Lien, ſplen. The milt. Dicitur & lienis in nominatiuo.
Ligur, incola Liguriae. An Italian of the countrey of Liguria.
Limax, teſtudo & cochlea terreſtris. The ſhelled ſhaile, and the dew ſnaile.
Limus, veſtis genus ab vmbiſico ad pedes, ceu lutum aut coenum mollius. A kind of garment, or els ſ • me or mudde.
• ngo, lambo, id eſt, aliquid lingua molliter tango. To licke.
• no, aliquid alicui rei ſuperinduco. To daube.
• nquo, committo, pecco. To leaue, to trespaſſe.
• ter, navicula 〈◊〉 cauata arbore facta. A cock-boat.
Linx, animal maculoſum, aentiſſime videns. Our men call this beast an Ounce.
Liqueſio, liqueſco. To be molten.
Liquor, liqueo. Idem.
Liueo, liuidus ſum, id eſt, ſordidus. To be wan, or filthy.

Lixa, coquus in exercitu, vel qui ſ •
quitur quaeſtus gratia. The Scolian that waiteth on an army.
Locri, vrbs in Brutiis. A towne in Jtalie.
Locus, proprie illud quod aliquid continer. A place.
Logos, ſermo, ratio, verbum. Speech, reaſon, a word.
Loquor, verba qualiacunque profero. To speake.
Luceo, lucem emitto. To be light.
Ludo, ludum exerceo, iocor. To play, or to sport.
Lues, cum in vrbe, aut in agro febris, aliudue morbi genus homines, aue pecora, aut vtroſque corrumpit. A common diſcaſeor murren.
Lugeo. To beiraile, to lament a thing, 〈◊〉 els abſolutely to mourne, and ſometime to be a mourner in apparell.
Luo, ſoluo, poenas do. To redeeme, to clenſe, to pay for.
Luſtra, habitacula ferarum. Dennes of wild beasts, or brothell houſes, and petty tippling houſes of baudry.

list.head: M
list.item: MEnalus, mons quidam Arcadiae. A hill of that name in Arcadia.
Magnes, lapis ferrum attrahens. A ſtone that draweth yron vnto it. Jt is called alſo Heraclius lapis: or Sideritis.
Maiores, aui, abaui, proaui, ataui, tritaui, & quicunque ante hos in infinitum. Our auncestours.
Malo, magis velim. To will rather.
Mando, comedo, vel committo. To eate, or to commit.
Maneo, ſiſto, & expecto. To tarrie, or to tary for.
Manes, dii inferi inter numina laeua. Spirits or deuils.
Manubiae, quae manu capiuntur ab hoſtibus. Spoyles taken in warres.
Manus, membrum notum. A band.
Mapalia, agreſtes c • ſae. Sheep-coates, or ſmall cottages.
Mare, pelagus. The Sea.
Margo, cuiuſque rei extremitas. The brinke or skirt of any thing, or the banke of a riuer or ſea.
Marm or, lapidis genus. Marble.
Mars, deus belli. The name of the god of warre.
Martyr, teſtis. A witnes, man or woman
Mas, vir. A man.
Maſſicus, mons Campaniae, optimi vini ferax. An hill in that part of Italy that is called Campania, fruitfull of pleaſant wines.
Mater, nota eſt ſignificatio. A mother.
Medeor, do medelam. To cure.
Medicor, medeor, remedium adfero. Idem.
Meio, mingo. To piſſe.
Mel, liquamen d • lce. Hony.
Meleager, vel Meleagrus, Oenei Aetoli aeregis filius. A mans name.
Menda, & mendum, error, erratum. A fault.
Menſes, mulierum proſſuvium. VVomens flowers.
Menſis, tempus lunae curriculo confectum. A moneth.
Mereor, aliquid facio, quamobrem dignus ſum obtiuere praemium vel poenam pati. To deſerue.
Meridies, dies medius. Noone, or the nooneſtead.
Metior, pondero, menſuro, conſidero. To meaſure.
Meto, ſeco, amputo herbam, velſegetem. To mowe.
Metuo, timeo. To feare.
Metuor, timeor. To be feared.
Meus, Mine.

Mico, fulgeo cum motu vel tremore. Often with certaine intermiſſions to ſhine, and likewiſe to be mooued, to put forth fingers to him with whome wee play, Will put foorth, which is called Micare digitis.
Miles, qui vel quae militiam exercet. A warrier, a ſouldier.
Mingo, vrinam facio. To piſſe, or to make water.
Minae, metus incuffiones per verba, aut ſigna. Threatnings.
Minores, poſteri, etiam poſt trinepotes futuri. Our ſucceſſours.
Miſceo. To mingle, to ſerue drinke, ſometime to trouble.
Miſereor, miſerecordia afficior. To take pirty on.
Mitto, ad aliquem do. To ſend.
Moenia, muri vrbis. The wals of a town, and figuratiuely the ton ne it ſelfe.
M • ereo, triſtor, dolore afficior. To be heauy, ſad, in a dumpe, or a mourning.
Monoptoton, nomen non flexum, ſe • carens omni caſu praeterquam vno • & eo obliquo. A noune hauing on termination, & that in one oblique ca •
Mons, terrae tumor altiſſimus. An hil •
Mordeo, dentibus laedo. To bite.
Morior, è vita diſcedo. To die.
Mos, vitae inſtitutum conſuetudin • firmatum. A custome.
Mulceo, lenio. To aſſwage.

Mulgeo, lacè mammis exprimo.
〈◊〉 milke.
Mulier, quae non eſt virgo. A wom •

Mulſum, potus ex vino & melle.
〈◊〉 certaine wine confect with honey.
Multiplico, adaugeo. To multiply, encreaſe.

Munia, onera legi debita, & offi • quae publicè praeſtantur. A du ••
or office.
Mus, exiguum animal. A Mouſe.

list.head: N
list.item: NAnciſcor, acquiro. To get, and to obtaine.
Naſcor, orior, in mundum venio. To be borne.

Natales, conditio ſanguinis & familiae. The degree of bloud and gentry, as, generoſi natales, natales obſcuri. It is alſo taken for yeares. Sex mihi natales iërant. There were paſſed ſixe yeeres. It is alſo vſed for the origine or firſt spring of things.
Natalis, dies alicui natalis. A birth day
Natrix, ſerpens aquatieus. A water ſerpent, that with poyſon infecteth the water.
Natu, aetate, partu. By age, or by birth.

Neco, quacun
que re te occido. To kill.
Necto, ligo, coniungo. To knit.
Negligo, contemno, non curo. Not to paſſe on, to contemne.
Nefrens, porculus per aetatem fabam frangere nondum potens. A young pigge.
Nigreo, niger fio. To become blacke.
Nemo, nullus homo. No body, man, or woman.
Neo, filum torqueo. To spinne.
Neuter. Neither of both.
Nervus, motus ſenſuſque inſtrumentum. A ſinewe.
Nexo, ligo vel necto. To bind.
Wycticorax, corvus nocturnus. A night rauen.
Video, ſplendeo. To ſhine.
Vihil, rei cuiuſuis priuatio. Nothing.
Vihilum, rei cuiuſuis priuatio.
Vil, vide nihil.
Vitor, conor, ago ſedulo. To goe about, to endeauour.
• iueo, eſt oculorū & aliorum membrorum niſu aliquid conari. To giue • token with the eyes, to winke, to ondeauour.
No, nato. To ſwimme.
Noceo, malum infero. To hurt, ort • harme.
Noctu, nocte. By night.
Nolo, renuo, non volo. To nill.
Nonae, quaſi nouae, propter initium obſeruationis. Erant autem in Martio, Maio, Iunio, & Octobri, ſex illi dies, qui calendas ſequebantur, in reliquis quatuor. The names of a moneth.
Noſco, rem certam habeo. To knowe.
Noſter. Ours.
Noſtras. Of our country, ſect, or faction.
Notus, ventus meridionalis, quem nos auſtrum appellamus. The ſouth wind
Nubes, vapor humidus ſublime egreſſus. A cloud.
Nubo, viro trador. To be married to a man: For it is in the womans part only.
Nugae, c • m nihil agimus. Trifles.
Nullus. None.
Nundinum, dies & conventus ſtatus rerum mercatui. A fayre.
Nuo. A verbe not much in vſe, the compounds thereof be commonly receiued, and it ſignifieth to nodde.
Nuptiae, legitima coniunctio maris & foeminae in vitae ſocietatem. Mariage.
Nurus, filii vxor. A daughter in law.

list.head: O
list.item: OBdo, oppono, ſiue appono. To ſet againſt.
Obex, obiectum aliquod, vel obſtaculum, vt peſſulum, ſera. A barre, or stoppe.
Obliuifcor, è memoria aliquid excidere ſino. To forget.
Obſes, qui vel quae traditur in fidem alteri. An hoſtage or pledge, man or woman.
Occido. To fall or periſh, and to be ſlaine.

Occiput, poſterior pars capitis. The
hinder part of the hend.
Occludo, claudo. To ſhu • .
Occulto, abſcondo, abdo. To hide.

Odor vel odos, quaſiolor ab oleo, eſt autem infectus aer.
〈◊〉 ſauour.
October, menſis octavus a Martio. The tenth maneth in our yeare, called October.
Oleaſter, olea ſylveſtris. A certaine ſhrubbilike the Oliue tree: the Greekes callit the wrlde Olius, or the ground Oliue for the lowneſſe.
Olco, odoremſpiro & emitto. Togiue a ſmell, and that indiffirently, ſo that the differences he made with bene and male.
Olfacio, odoror. To ſmell, or to ſanour a thing: by tranſlation it is to perceiue, and finde, to foreſee.
Omon, augurium quod fit ore. Halſoning, and forespeaking.
Omnis. Euery one.
Onus, pondus alicui iniunctum. A burden.
Onyx, vnguis, & gemma. The nayle of a mans hand, a precious ſtone white like a nayle, the haw in a mans eye.
Operio, tego. To couer.
Opis, adminiculi, praeſidii. Of aide, and helpe.
Opifex, quì opus facit. A workeman.
Oppango, circumſigo, circumplanto. Tofaſten, or to ioyne vnto, or to plant •• out.
Opus Opuntis, nomen ciuitatis in Locris. At • wnes name in the countrey of Locris.
Orbis, circulus mundi, res rotunda. A Globe, or a bowk, and thereof the world iscalled Orbis, becauſe it is euery way round like a bowle.
Ordior, incipio. To beginne, or to commence.
Ordior, id eſt, texo. To weaue.
Oriens, regio orientalis. The Eaſt.
Orior, naſcor, ſurgo, incipio. To ſpring, to riſe, to begin.
Orontes, nomen viri, & fluvii. A mans name, or a certameriner in Syria, now called Tarſaro.
Os oris, concavum illud intra quod ſunt dentes, & lingua. A mouth.
Os oſſis, ſolidamentum corporis durum. A bone.
Oſtreum, conchae ſpecies. An Oyſter.
Ovum. An Egge.

list.head: P
list.item: PAciſcor, pactum facio, conuenio, To make a bargaine, to fall to an accord, and ſometime to promiſe.
Palleo, parùm albeo. To be pale.
Pampinus, vitis ramus. A vinebranch.
Pando, aperio, patefacio. To open.
Pango, paciſcor, cano, iungo, plango, figo. To bargame, to ſing, to toyne, to wayle, to faſten.
Panis, quo paſcimur. Bread.
Panther, & panthera, animal quoddi pardo ſunile. Acertaine beaſt.
Papauer, genus herbae ſoporiferum, Poppie.

Papyrus, charta qua vtimur in litter is ſcribendis. A certaine ſort of ruſ •• growing in the mariſh of Egypt, ſomen hat high, whereof they made a kind of paper, & called it Papyrus,
〈◊〉 her • of our paper now is called likewiſt.

Paradiſus, locus amoeniſſimus.
• place of pleaſure.

Partio, diuido, & quaſi partes faci •
To part ordiuide.
Parco, abſtineo ab vltione. To 〈◊〉
Parco, obedio. To obey.
Pario, prolem produco. To bring f • rt •
Parens, pater aut mater, avus aut 〈◊〉 via. A father or mother, a gran ••• theror grandmother.
Parnaſſus, mons in Phoeide, du • vertices habens. An hill in Ph ••• a countrey of Greece.

Parturio, cupio, aut conor parere 〈◊〉
be toward labour.
Paſco, nutrio. To feed, to nouriſh.
Paſcor, nutrior, alor. To be fed.
Paſſer, auis ſalaciſſina. A Sparrow.
Pateo, apertus ſum. To be open.
Patior, ſuſtinco, tolero. To ſuffer, or to abide.
Patro, aliquid mali committo. To commit ſome euill.
Patrueles, patruorum filii. Brothers children.
Paueo, timeo. To feare.
Pecten, inſtrumentum textorum, & dentatum. A combe, or a weauers ſley.
Pecto, orno capillos. To combe the haire.
Pecus, cudis, oris, omne animal quod ſub hominis imperi s pabulo terrae paſcitur. All cattell.
Pedes, qui pedibus incedit. A fcoteman.
Pedo, ventris crepitum facio. To fart.
Pelagus, mare. The ſea.
Pellex, mulier impudica. An harlot.
Pello, eiicio, remoueo. To drius, or to put away.
Penates, dii domeſtici, quod penes nos nati ſunt. Houſhold gods.
Pendco, ſuſpenſus ſum. To be hanged.
Pendo, ſuſpendo, vel pondero, aeſtimo. To hang, to waigh, to priſe.
Penis, cauda. A tayle, &c.
Penis, vel penum, omne eſculentum, poculentum quo homines veſcuntur. All manner of victuall.
Perago, perficio. To finiſh, and to perfect buſineſſe.
Perlego, totum lego. VVholly and throughly to reade.
Percutio, ferio. To ſinite.
Perdix, auis nota. A Partridge.
Perdo, amitto. To loſe.
Perduellis, hoſtis. An enemy in the warres.
Pergamus, ciuitas inſignis Afiae in diuone Troianorum. The citie of the Troians, otherwiſe called Ilium or Ilion.
Pergo, in re procedo, abeo. To g •• forward.
Permiſſu, permiſſione, cum nemo aduerſatur. By ſufferance, with leaue and licence.
Perpetior, multum cum laboro ac dolore patior. Throughly to beare or ſuffer.
Perplaceo, valde placeo. To pleaſe very much, or throughly to pleaſe.
Perſis, orientalis regio. The countrey of Perſia.
Pes, im a pars corporis qua gradimur. A foote.
Peto, oro, obſecro, volo. To aske.
Phalerae, ornamenta equorum. Horſa trappings.
Phaſus, turris altiſſima in portu, quae lucet nauigantibus. A watch tower.
Phaſelus, nauicula velox & oblonga. A brigandine.
Philotis, nomen mulieris. A womans name.
Phoenix, auis in oriente, à Phcenice • pennarum colore dicta, toto orbc celeberrima, in Arabia naſceus, aquilae magnitudine. Phenix the b • d.
Phryx, vir Phrygiae. A Troian.
Pietas, pius cultus. Godlineſſe.
Piger, dolet, ſeu moleſtum eſt. I • irketh
Pingo, formam aliculus rei ductis lineis repra ſento. To paint.
Pinſo, tundo, panem conficio. To ſinite with the beake, to be it in a morter, as on • e they did their graine, and thereof to bake.
Pinus, arbor eſt picci generis, nucc • ferens omnium maximas, quat Latini pineas vocant. A pine tree.
Piper, herba. Pepper.
Piſcis, animal quod continue ſu •• aquis degit. A ſiſh.
Pix, reſina ex a rboribus fluens. Pi ••• .

Python, ſerpens è putredine natus.
Serpent.
Placeo, gratus ſum. To pleaſo.
Plagae, retia rariora ad capiendas feras. Hunting nets, or wide meaſhed nets to take beasts.
Plaudo, manibus percutio, ae geſtu laetitiam indico. To clap hands for ioy
Plebes, vel plebis, idem quod vulgus. The common people.
Plecto, ſupplicio afficio, punio, ferio. To puniſh, to beate.
Pleo, plenum facio. To fill.
Plico, contraho, & rugas facio. To fold, or to plaite.
Pluo, aquam demitto. To raine.
Plus, vox incrementi. More.
Polleo, poſſum, valeo. To be able, to be of power, and ſometime it is taken for to paſſe, or to be better, or mora profitable.
Pons, aſſer, velquoduis aliud per quod ſuper aquas tranſunus. A bridge.
Pono, colloco, conſtituo. To ſit, or to put.
Pontus, mare. The Sea.
Porticus, ampla domus propter repentinos imbres de ambulationis gratia aedificara. A Galerie, or an ambulatorie.
Poſco, peto. To a • ke, and to require.
Poſtis, latus portae ſiue ianua. A poſt.
Poto, bibo. To drinke.
Praecordia, quae exta ſeparant ab inferiore viſcerum parte. The midderiffe.
Praecurro, antccurro, ſiue cito ante co To ru • ne before.
Praelego, antelego, vt ſolent praeceptores ſuis diſcipulis. To be an interpretor, or a Reader, and ſometime to cut, or to ſayle by.
Praeminco, praecello. To excell other.
Praeſul, qui vel quae praecſt. He or ſhee that ſuperintendeth.
Praeſcs, qui vel quae praeſider, Idem.
Prandeo, prandium ſumo, vel ante prandium cibum ſumo. To diue.
Precis, precationis, obſecrationis. Of prayer, of petition.
Premo. To preſſe, to be against, and to vexe, to puſh, and to be hard at hand with, to driue, to hide, to expell, to ſhut, to deſlowre, or kill, &c.
Preneſte, nomen vrbis. A towne in Italie.
Pres, ſponſor qui ſe obligat, id eſt, fide iuſſor in lite nummaria. A ſurety
Princeps, qui vel quae prineipatum obtinet. The Prince, or Princeſse.
Primitiae, primi fructus ex agro percepti, qui deo offeruntur. Firſt fruits of a mans grounds, or the firſtlings of any other thing.
Problema, propoſitio interrogationem annexam habens. A demaund.
Prodo, manifeſto. To betray, to make manifeſt.
Proficiſcor, eo aliò. To goe forth.
Proluo, multum ſiue multo tempore lauo. To all to waſh.
Promineo, procul appareo. To hang out in ſight.
Promo, profero, cloquor. To ſet • broach, or to vtter.
Promptu, paratè, ſine mora. VVi • readmeſſe or ſpeed.
Pſallo, cano inſtrumento muſico. T • ſing, or to play on an inſtrument.
Puber, vel Pubes, propriè lanug • quae maribus decimoquarto ann • foeminis duodecimo circa pude • da oriri incipit. Ripenes of age.
Pudet, pudore afficior. It ſhameth.
Pucraſco, exacta infantia pueritia inchoo. To waxe a child.
Pugil, qui vel quae pugnandi art • nouit. A champion man or wom •
Puluis, & pulver. Duſt. notum eſt
Punctus, & punctum, minima indi • duaque lineae pars. A pricke, 〈◊〉 point, a little centre.

Pungo, ſtimulo, morſum ac acul •
infigo. To pricke, or to ſting.
Pumex, lapis cauernoſus. A Pummis ſtone.
P • s, ſanies, & quicunque humor in putredinem verſus. Maſter or Core.

list.head: Q
list.item: QVaero, inueſtigo, interrogo. To ſeeke for, to ſearch.
Quatio, mouco, concutio. To ſhake.
Quercus. An Oake.
Queror, lamentor. To complaine and lament.
Qui. The which.
Quies, vacatio à labore, aut ceſſatio à quouis opere. Reſt, it appertaineth to the bodie. Tranquillitas, vnr • the minde.
Quilibet. Euery one, or whoſoeuer yee will.
Quiniſco, caput inclino, moueo. To hang the head.
Quiſquiliae, purgamenta, & quicquid ex arboribus ſurculorum, foliorum, aut florum minutim decidit. Things of no weight. Things not worthy regard, or chippings.
Quot. How many.

list.head: R
list.item: RAbula, homo futilis. A brawler, or a ſmatterer in the Law.
Rado, cultro vel quauis re acuta decerpo. To ſhaue.
Ramex, ruptura, & diſtentio inteſtinorum. Burſtneſſe.
Rapio, per vim traho, aufero. To ſnatch away.
Raſtrum, inſtrumentum dentatum, quo vtimur in foenificio ad corradendum faenum. A rake.
Raucio, raucus ſum. To be hoarſe.
Recido, retrò ſiue iterum in eadem cado. To fall backeward, or to fall into the ſame againe.
Recordor, rurſus in mentem reuoco, To call to minde againe.
Reddo, acceptum vel ablatum reſtituo. To render, or to restore.
Redoleo, odorem alicuius rei refero, vel multum oleo. To beare the ſau • r of a thing, or to ſauour ſtrongly, & by a metaphor to reſemble, and to tast of.
Refringo, iterum frango. To breake open.
Rego, guberno. To rule or rouerne.
Relego, rurſus lego. To reade againe.
Reminiſcor, recordor, memini. To remember.
Ren, viſcus quoddam. The kidney.
Renuo, refuto, reiicio. To refuſe.
Reor, a bitror, puto. To ſuppoſe.
Repango, diſſoluo, reiungo. To vnlooſe, to diſ • gyne.
Reperio, inuenio. To finde.
Replico, diſſoluo. To vnfold.
Repetundarum, alicnarum pecuniarum, de quibus praeſes prouinciae a prouinc: alibus accuſatur, ſi qua • v • aut dolo expilauit. Of briberia, and pillage, or of extortion.
Repugno, iterum ſtimulo vicem reddo. To pricke againe.
Res, omnia ſiue corporalia, ſiue incorporalia comprehendit. A thing.
Reſcio, rurſum percipio. To knowe againe.
Reſpuo, repudio, ſperno. To refuſe.
Reſtis, funis vel lorum. A rope, or a with.
Reſulto, reſilio, reuertor, in contrarium ſalio. To rebound.
Rete, inſtrumentum quo piſces capiuntur. A net.
Rex, nota eſt ſignificatio. A King.
Rideo, cachinno. To laugh.
Ringo, os torqueo vt canes. To make an euill fauoured face like a ſnarring dogge, and to vexe.
Robur, ſpecies quercus duriſſimae. An • ake.
Rodo, mordeo, comedo. To gnawe.
Roma, vrbs Italiae quondam à paſtoribus condita, olim gentium domina eum floreret, quarta & poſtrema Monarchia. Rome.
Ros, humor qui ſereno tempore à caelo fluit. Adem.
Roſtra, templum ſen forum iudiciale ante curiam Hoſtiliam in quo erat pulpitam, ex quo concionari ſolebant. The place where matters be deelamed.
Rudens, funis nauticus. A cable.
Rudo, grauiter ſono vt aſini. To cri • like an aſſe.
Rumpo, frango. To breake.
Ruo, cado. To fall.
Rus, locus extra vrbem, vbi agri ſunt & villae. The countrey.

list.head: S
list.item: SAcer, quod venerabile. Holy.
Sacerdos, deo dicatus ad ſacrificia facienda. A Prieſt or a Nunne.
Sacro, deo dedico, ſacrum facio. To delicate.
Sal, quo vtimur in cibis condiendis. Salt.
Salio, ſalto. To le • pe, or to leape as bruite beasts do when the male couereth the female.
Sallo, ſale condio, ac conſpergo. To ſalt, to powder, or to ſeaſon with ſalt.
Salto. To leape, or to dance.
Salum, mare, à ſapore ſalis. The ſea.
Salus, incolumitas. Health.
Samnis, nomen gentis. A Samnite.
Sancio, firmo, & propriè effuſo ſanguine per hoſtiae immolationem. To make ſure, and to eſtabliſh.
Sanguis, cruor qui ex vulnere ſpargitur. Blood.
Sapientia, rerúm diuinarum atque humanarum ſcientia. VViſedome.
Sapio, ſaporem habeo. To haue a taſt.
Sapphitus, pretioſus lapis. A Saphyre.
Sarcio, purgo, reficio, integrum facio. To patch, and amend.
Sardonyx. A certaine precioue ſtone.
Satago, ſatis ago, laboro, ſolicitus ſum. To doe ende • uour.
Satrapas, princeps. A Prince.
Scabo, frico. To ſeratch, or to rubbe.
Scalpo, ſculpo, & fodio vnguibus ae manibus. To claw, or to ſcratch.
Scando, in altum tendo. To climbe.
Scindo, feco, findo. To cut, or to diuide.
Scio. To knowe.
Scobis & ſcobs, eſt id quod ab aliqua materia decidit per ſerram, terebram, aut limam. Duſt.
Scriba, qui literas, vel geſta, veltabellas, & ſimilia ſcribit alterius nomine. A Scribe, or Notarie.
Scribo, literas formo. To write.
Scrobs, foſſa aut puteus. A ditch, or 〈◊〉 pit.
Scurra, qui riſum ab auditoribus captat, non habita ratione verecundiae, aut dignitatis. A ſcoffer, auſter, a paraſite.
Secerno, abiungo, ſeparo. To diuid • to ſeparate.
Seco, diuido. To cut.
Sedeo, quieſco. Toſit.
Seges, frumentum in ſpicis. Corne ye • ſtanding.
Seligo, ſeorſum colligo. To gathey 〈◊〉 part.

Semis, id eſt, ſemias, ſex vneiae, dim •
dium aſſis, Halfe a pound or the hal • of any whole ſumme.
Senecta vel ſenectus, ſenium, aetas. Onage.
Senex, ſenio confectus. An olde ma •
Senio, quod ſex puncta continet.
Senium, idem quod ſenecta.
Senſus & ſenſum, organum ſentien • & quod mente concipitur. Any the fiue wits called the ſenſes, or t •• that the minde conceiueth, called meaning.

Sentio, alique ſenſu percipio, P ••
intelligo ponitur. To pereaiue by ſome ſenſe, or to vnderstand.
Sentis, ſpina. A thorne.
Sepelio, defunctum terra condo. To burie.
Sepio, obſtruo, circundo, munio. To compaſſe, to hedge.
Seps, ſerpens parvus. A little ſerpent, after whoſe stroke the members do r • t
Sequor, abeuntem ſubſequor. To follow.
Ser, popul •• Aſiae. One of a certaine people in Aſia called Scres.
Sermo, loquela. Speech.
Sero, ſemino, planto. To ſow, or plant, or to graft, and ſometime by tranſlation to beget: by tranſlation alſo we ſay, ſerere bella, ſerere certamina, id eſt, mouere lites & pugnas.
Serpens, anguis, A dragon, or ſerpent, or a ſnake.
Sibilus, eſt quidam ſtridor oris per anguſtam ſpiritus emiſſionem, inter dentes fere. An hiſſing.
Sido, deſcendo ad ſedendum. To pitch, or to lie downe.
Siler, arbor quam vulgo ſalieem vocant. An Oſier, with this difference Montanum, it ſignifies a ſimple that the Apothecaries doe vſe, in Latine called Seccli Maſſilienſe.
Silex, lapis duniſſimus, vnde ignis excutitur. A flint-ſtone.
Sinapis, & ſinapi, herba eſt ſemen ferens, tanta acrimonia, vt lachrymas cieat comedenti. Scenic.
Sindon, velum ſubtiliſſimum. Sendal.
Singultio, grauiter tuffin, & ſingultum emitto. To ſob.
Sino, permitto. To ſuffer.
Sinus & ſinum, genus vaſis ſinuoſi. A boule or diſh for milke or wine to drinke of.
S • ren, monſtrum maris. A Mearemaide.
S • er, herba cuius radix praecipuè eſt in vſu. A Perſenep.
Siſto, ſtare ſacio. To bring before.
Sitis, deſiderium potionis. A thirſt.
Synodus, conuentus. A councell congregate.
Soboles, ſucceſſio. An off-spring.
Socrus, vxoris vel mariti mater. Amother in law.
Sodalis, eiuſdem ſortis ſocius. A followe.
Sol, qui Phoebus dicitur. The Sunne.
Soleo, ſuctus ſum. To be wont.
Solium, ſella regia, in quareges ius dicentes, ſedebant. A throne, or a chaire of state.
Soluo, quod ligatum erat diſſoluo, ac enodo. To loſe.
Somnus, ſopor, quies. Sleepe.
Sono, ſonum facio. To ſound.
Sorbeo, deglutio quicquam molle. To ſuppe.
Soror, notum eſt. A Siſter.
Spargo, late proiicio, ac paſſim iacto. To sparkle, or sprinkle.
Species, effigies, aromata, genus, viſio. A forme, spice, the kind of a thing, or an appearance.
Specio, video. To ſee.
Specus, ſpelunca, vnde ſpectare licet. A denne to await a prey.
Sperno, deſpicio, comemno. To deſpiſe.
Spinus, agreſtium prunornm arbor. A Sloe tree.
Splen, lien, viſcus quoddam. The milt.
Spondeo, ſponte promitto. To premiſe, and ſometime to betroth.
Sponſalia, promiſſio ſiue ſtipulatio futurarum nuptiarum. Betrothing with conditions taken.
Spontis, naturae & ingenii propri • . Of nature and owne dispoſition.
Statuo, pono, colloco, erigo. To place, to ſet vp, ſometime to decree and appoint, ſomtime to dedicats, & ſet before.
Sterno, proiicio in terram. To thr • xe 〈◊〉 , or to spread.
Sterto, dormio, & ſomnum altum dormiendo capio. To ſleepe till wee ſ ••• rt.
Stipis, & ſtips, pecuniae genus quod per capita colligere ſolent. A money gathered by the poll for the vſe of the gode, • r for the poore, and therfore it ſignifieth alſo a reward, or a profit.
Stirps, origo, progenies, ſoboles. A stocke, a tr • be, a deſeent, and ſomtime it is the bodie of a tree, idem quod truncus.
Sto, erect • s ſum, vel maneo. To ſtand
Strepo, fonum facio. To make a noyſe.
Strido, ſtrepitum edo. To make a noiſe, whiſſing, or a crooking.
Strideo, facio ſtridorem, ſonum violent •• n. To make a g • eat noiſe, or to gnaſh with teeth. It is applyed alſo to wheeles, to doore-hookes, to ſerpents, to the Sea, and ſuch other things.
Stringo, premo, arcto. To make ſtrait, to pull, ſometime to ſtrike.
Struo. To build, to pile vp, & ſometime to endeauour, and to go about, or to ſet in aray.
Stultitia, imprudentia, ſtoliditas. Fooliſhneſſe.
Suadeo, hortor ad id quod intendo. To counſell.
Suber, genus ligni quod nautis vtile eſt vt ſupernatent retia. A corketree.
Sublego, furto aliquid ſurripio. Priuily to ſteale away.
Suboleo, leuiter oleo, ſiue odoratus ſenſu leuiter percipio. To ſauour, or to ſmell a thing a little, and by tranſtation to be eſpied, and to bee ſmelled out.
Suffero, ſuſtineo, patior. To ſustaine, or abide.
Sueſco, ſoleo. To be accustomed.
Sugo, ſpiritu attraho ſuccum. To ſuck.
Sulmo, oppidum in Brutiis. A towne.
Sum. To he.
Sumo, multam, & penè nimium mihi. To take.
Supellex, res domeſtica. Houſholde ſtuffe.
Supplico, humiliter & cum reuerentia precor. To entreate.
Suppetiae, auxilium, ſubſidium. Aid, helpe, ſuccour.
Surgo, erigo me. To ariſe, ſometime to ſpring, or to grone, to increaſe. It is alſo to ariſe by little and little, as things doe in building.
Sus, animal ſordidum. A Boare, Sow, or Hogge.

list.head: T
list.item: TAceo, ſileo, non loquor. To keepe ſilence.
Taedet, pertaeſum eſt, diſplicet. It irketh or wearieth.

Taenarus, locus vmbroſus in radice Malex, promontorii Laconiae iuxt • Spartam ciuitatem, in quo quia hiatus magnus eſt, & ſtrepitus qua •• progredientium ſentitur, dixerun veteres per hunc eſſe deſcenſun adinferos. A Promontorie in Lac •
nia, wherein is an entrance to go don • to Hell.

Tagus, fluvius Luſitaniae habens are nas aureas. A certaine riuer in Po •
tugall.

Talio, vindicta, hoſtimentum. A •
uengement, or like for like.
Talpa, animal captum oculis, mu • ſimile. A Moule, or want.
Tango, percutio. To touch.
Tartarus, dimiſſior inferni locus. H •
Tantundein, aeque tantum. As mu •

Tapes, vel Tapetum, vel tapete, id e •
panni depictitegimen, mirè pict • variis coloribus. A carpet or c •• of Arras.

Tagetus, mons in Laconide, Baec •
ſacer, ſub quo Sparta & Amiclae. An hill in Lacedemonia, where Sparta and Amiclae the cities do ſtand.
Teges, vile ſtragulum, matta ſcirpia. Amat.
Thebae, nomen quarundam vrbium. The name of a city in Aegypt, and of another in Boeotia, you ſhall find alſo in Authors Thebae and Theba.
Thermae, loca aquas habentia, aut naturae ſponte calentes, aut fornace calefactas, fundendi lauandiue vſibus ſeruata. Hot baths.
Temno, ſperno. To despiſe.

Tempe, pulcherrimus ager in Theſſalia, quem Peneus alluit. A very faire field in Theſſalia, moſt pleaſant to behold, and therefore appellatiuely it may be vſed for a place of delight, at Paradiſe & Eliſium is. There is alſo Tempe is Boeotia, called Temneſia Tempe: another in Sicilie, named for difference Helorix: the first is called Theſſalia Tempe.
Tendo, expando. To ſtretch, and to bend.
Teneo, apprehendo. To hold.
Tepeo, in medio inter tepidum & frigidum ſum. To be warme.
Tepeſco, tepidus ſio. To waxe hot.
Ternio, numerus ternarius. The three.
Tero, comminuo, conſumo, tundo. To weare by diminiſhing.
Teſqua, loca edita aſpera.
Teuerus, Teucer, nomen proprium Troianorum regis. Aname of a certaine king of Troy.
Trado, in poteſtatem alterius tranſfero. To deliuer vnto another.
Tros, nomen viri. A Troian.
Teſtis, qui vel quae teſtimonium profert. A witneſſe, man or woman.
Texo, telam ſtruo ac paro. To weaue.
•• gnus, tignum, trabs qua variè diſpoſita domus extruitur. A rafier.
• nitrus, & tonitru nubis ictae, ſeu potius diruptae ſonus. Thunder.
Torqueo. To writh, to wrest, to winde, or turne about, to geuerue, to torment, to spinne, to vexe and trouble, to whurle, &c.
Tot. So many, or many.
Thorax, pectus, & pectoris munimentum. The breaſt and breaſt place.
Thrax, vir Thraciae. A Thraciam.
Thus, incenſum, libamen quo deum veneramur, aliquando ipſa arbor. Frank incenſe, and the tree.
Tybris, fluvius Italiae.
Tibur, oppidum Italiae.
Tigris, animal velociſſimuth & truculentum. Alygre.
Timeo, metuo. To feare.
Timeor, metuor. To be feared.
Titubo, lingua vel pedibus vacillo. To stumble or ſtammer.
Tollo, eleuo, ſubleuo. To lift vp, to bring vp as children are by •• rſing, or elſe to ſlay, or take away.
Tondeo, crines vel lanam ſeco forcipe. Tô clip or ſheare.
Tono, valdè ſono, ac facio tomitrum. To thunder.
Torpeo, languidus ſum & romiſſus. To be ſluggiſh, and weake.
Torquis, circulus aureus, collique ornamentum. A chaine to aderne the necke.
Torreo, vro, aſſo. To roſt.
Torrens, fluvius per pluviam collectus. A lake without spring begunne by raine.
Torris, lignum ardens vel aduſtum. A fire-brand.
Tracto, traho, vel ſurſum traho. To pul, and to dra • e vp, or to handle by faire or fowle meanes.
Tra • o, vi ad me rapio, ac duco. To drawe.
Tranſlego, legendo tranſcurro, ac perlego. To reade ouer.
Tremo, cōmoueor, agitor. To tremble.
Tres. Three.
Tribus, progenies. A kinred.
Tricae, capilli pedibus pullorum Gallinaceorum inuoluti. Lets or ſtops, or hinderances of that, that chickens ſo vſed could but euill goe.
Triptoton, nomen quod tribus quibuſcunque caſibus inflectitur. A Noune declined with three caſes.
Trudo, manibus pedibuſue impello. To thruſt.
Tu. Thou.
Tuber, dictum à tumendo, & priore longa, terrae callus. A ſwelling in any thing, a muſhrom, or that whereof the puſh is.
Tueor, defendo. To defend.
Tuor, video. To ſee.
Tundo, decutio, pulſo. To beat, or to knocke.
Tuſſis, vehemens ſpiritus eruptio, ea quae meatum ſuum obſtruunt exoutere conantis. The eough.

list.head: V
list.item: VAdo, eo. To gee.
Valeo, poſſum, validus ac ſanus ſum. To be in health, or to be able.
Valuae, ſuntfores geminas habentes partes in ſe cocuntes. A two leaſed •• ore.
Vannus. A vanne to winnowe corne with.
Vas vadis, vadimonium. A ſurety in a matter of debt.
Vas vaſis, inſtrumentum ad aliquid capiendum idoneum. A veſſell.
Vates, poeta, & qui futura praedicit. A Prophet or Propheteſſe.
Vber. The adiectiue ſignifieth plentifull, abundant, copious: the ſubſtantine ſignifieth a pap or a dugge, or an vdder: and ſometime it is found for plentifulnes, as Vber agri, for fertilitas agri.
Verberis, hoc non videtur defici vllo caſu. Vide Verber.
Vectis, inſtrumentum quo elauditu • oſtium. A doere barre.
Vcho, nau • , plauſtro, quadrupede porto. To carrie.
Vello, traho, extirpo. To pull, or i • plucke vp.
Vendo, venundo, alieno. To ſell.
Veneo, vendor. To be ſold.
Venio, ad aliquem accedo. To conn.
Venter, qui à pectore ad pubem terminatur. A belly.
Venus, dea amoris, & vennſtatis. The goddeſſe of loue and beautie.
Ver, anni pare temperatior. The spring time.
Verber, inſtrumentum longum verberandi. Any thing that wee b • ate withall, as r • d, whip, wand, or other. It ſignifieth alſo the ſtripe.
Vergco, tendo, declino. To bend, 〈◊〉 goe, or to encline ſome way.
Vermis, à vertendo, quia ſeſe torquendorepit. Aworme.

Verna, en ancilla domi natus ſervus. A bond man borne of a bond 〈◊〉 at home. It is vſed adiectiuely for th •• that is donesticall, or not ſtrange, 〈◊〉
vinum verna.
Verres, porcus non caſtratus. An log •
Verro, purgo, traho. To ſw • epe.
Verto, muto, voluo. To turne, or 〈◊〉 change.
Veruex, mas inter oues, cui ademp • ſunt teſticuli. A VVeather.
Veſcor, vtor eibo, & paſco. To ea ••
Veſper, idem quod Heſperus. It called alſo veſperugo, and it is take for the euening tide.
Veto, prohibeo. To forbid.
Vicem, viciſſitudinem. An into • change when turnes be.
Video, oculis intucor. To ſee.

Vieo, ligo ſeu inflecto. To binde, or bewe, thereof Victores be called C •
pers, qui vaſa vinaria religant.
Vigil, qui vel quae vigilat. A watcher 〈◊〉 or woman.
Vincio, ligo. To binde.
Vinco, ſupero. To ouercome.
Vindex, qui vel quae vindicat. An auenger man or woman.
Vir, notum eſt. A man.
Virgilius Poeta. A Poets name.
Virgo, quae non eſt paſſa virum. A Ʋirgiue.
Vitrum, materia tranſlucida, quae ex arena, & cinere fit. Glaſſe.
Virtus, ar • recte beneque vinendi. Ʋertue or great power.
Virus, venenum, & grauis odor. Poyſon, or ſtench.
• is, virtus, robur, ſortitudo, natura, violentia. Strength, power, nature, vieſence.
• ſo, en ad videndum. To goe to ſee.
• iſcum, vel viſcus, id eſt, glatinum ad • ucupium. Birdlime.
〈◊〉 , vitam ago. To liue.
Vleiſcor, vindico. To avenge.
Vnguis, durities digitorum, tam in auibus caeteriſque beſtiis, quam in homine. A naile, a hoofe, and • talan •
Vocito, frequenter voco. Often to eal.

Volo, as. To fle • , or to g • e apa •• : as Nauis volat: Fama volat. B ••
volo, vis, is to will, or to bewilling.
Voluo, verto. To rowle.
Vomis, vel vomer, nomen habet quod terram vomat. The plowſhare.
Vomo, per os eiicio. To vemit, or to parbreake.
Vrgeo, premo, compello. To thre • t.
Vro, ardore aut frigore, nonnunquam alia vi la do. And by tranſlation to hurt, or to grieue.
Vtor, vſum rei habeo. To vſe.
Vulgus, multitudo ignobilis. The baſe and common people.
Vulpes, animal aſtutum. A Fex, or a Fix • n.
Vxor, viri coniux. A wiſe.

div.p: Finis interpretationis omnium Nominum & Verborum Grammatices REGIAE.
MDCXXI.
